Mr BURKE (Watson—Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Minister for the Arts and Leader of the House) (12:04): I declare that unless otherwise ordered the following bills stand referred to the Federation Chamber for further consideration: (1) Parliamentary Business Resources Legislation Amendment (Review Implementation and Other Measures) Bill 2024, Criminal Code Amendment (Protecting Commonwealth Frontline Workers) Bill 2024, Illegal Logging Prohibition Amendment (Strengthening Measures to Prevent Illegal Timber Trade) Bill 2024, Treasury Laws Amendment (Financial Market Infrastructure and Other Measures) Bill 2024, Australian Postal Corporation and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2024 and Financial Framework (Supplementary Powers) Amendment Bill 2024, at the adjournment of the debate on the motion for the second reading of each bill; and (2) Digital ID Bill 2024 and Digital ID (Transitional and Consequential Provisions) Bill 2023, at the adjournment of the debate on the motion for the second reading of the Digital ID Bill 2024.
BUSINESS
Orders of the Day

Mr BURKE (Watson—Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Minister for the Arts and Leader of the House) (12:05): I declare Federation Chamber order of the day No. 1, government business, relating to the Prime Minister's motion of condolence in connection with the death of Lance Corporal Jack Patrick Fitzgibbon is returned to the House for further consideration.
MOTIONS
Climate Change
Mr BANDT (Melbourne—Leader of the Australian Greens) (12:05): I move:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Member for Melbourne moving the following motion:
That the House:
(1) notes the world is on track for a catastrophic 2.5 to 3 degree warming of the planet based on current policies;
(2) acknowledges that coal and gas are fuelling the climate crisis;
(3) condemns the Future Gas Strategy which intends to expand gas production to 2050 and beyond; and
(4) calls on the Environment Minister and Resources Minister to stop approving new coal and gas mines.

We are in a climate crisis. With scientists on the weekend saying that they are despairing at the possibility of delivering something close to a safe climate to our kids and grandkids, with people in the Northern Rivers of New South Wales still unable to get back into their homes after the devastating floods, with people in Queensland and Brisbane unable to afford to insure their houses because the risk of coal and gas fuelled floods is now so severe, and with the Great Barrier Reef bleaching yet again on the very same day that the Prime Minister and the resources minister turn up to celebrate the thousandth gas shipment going out of ports there, it is vital that today we debate now and call on the government to stop approving new coal and gas mines.

What is crystal clear now, after the announcements we've seen over the last few days, is that Labor want coal and gas past 2050, at a time when they told us they were going to get to zero pollution. They now want it past 2050. The environment minister has approved coalmines to run past 2050. The government now, in a cabinet endorsed gas strategy, says they want gas to 2050 and beyond. 2050 would have been too late to reach zero, but now we're not even going to reach it then, because Labor's policy, crystal clear, is to keep opening new coal and gas mines and have it running past 2050, even though every scientist is telling us that that is a recipe for catastrophic heatwaves and floods and fires for people who are going to primary school today. It means that during the lifetime of kids at primary school today they will see Australia lose its capacity to feed itself as the Murray-Darling Basin evaporates and becomes 92 per cent less productive than it is at the moment. It will mean they go to every school holidays and Christmas holidays worried about how many people are going to die in the heatwaves and bushfires that will hit that year, because this parliament and this government failed to get the climate crisis under control.

Five new coal projects and eight new gas projects—that's what the Labor government have approved since they came to power. And now they have embraced Scott Morrison. The Prime Minister is now worse than Scott Morrison, pushing for new gas projects and having them go past 2050, at a time when we should be at absolutely zero pollution, if not much sooner.

You know what, Mr Speaker? At 5.15 the day after parliament rose last time, after we had been sitting here for weeks debating gas, we found out that the environment minister had secretly approved the pipeline for the Beetaloo gas project. She didn't tell parliament about it. It just happened to become public the day after scrutiny could have been put on them in question time while parliament was sitting here.

I want to make a special mention of those lions in their electorates who are mice in the parliament, the members for Macnamara, Wills, Richmond, Cooper and Moreton, all of whom sat here and cheered on every one of those new coal and gas mines when they were approved. Now, apparently, they're saying that there's a problem with the government's gas strategy. Well, this is a chance to come and vote on it. There's one thing that you get here that everyday people don't get: when you come to parliament, you get your vote. People want to know whether you're going to vote for more coal and gas mines or vote against them. This is a chance now to put your money where your mouth is and be on the right side of history. Stop approving new coal and gas mines. Come and vote with those of us in the Greens and on the crossbench who know the science and want to stop seeing this climate crisis get worse. If you don't—if your party doesn't let you—then quit your party. It is crystal clear now that Labor's policy is for more coal and gas past 2050, unless we stop them with this motion today and a commitment from the government that they will stop opening new coal and gas projects.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?
Mr CHANDLER-MATHER (Griffith) (12:11): I second the motion. It is clear that gas corporations run the Australian Labor Party. It is so abundantly clear. There are three reasons why.
Mr Perrett: Rubbish!

Mr CHANDLER-MATHER: We hear objections immediately; it feels like we maybe touched a nerve again. Firstly, they let gas corporations get away with paying next to no tax. On income tax, Santos pays less income tax than anyone watching this at home. We also know that Santos last year wrote to the Labor resource minister asking for changes to environmental approvals to allow them to accelerate the approval of the Barossa gas project, and then Labor did just that, overriding the wishes of First Nations people and serious environmental concerns. Any other constituent in Australia would love the idea that they could write to the minister and then immediately get what they want. What about all the people on JobSeeker writing to the minister, asking to have their payments raised above the poverty line, or the people stuck on waiting lists or the renters out there? They get ignored. But, if you're the CEO of Santos, you get exactly what you want.

We also know that this new gas strategy is something of which every Labor member in this place should be deeply, deeply ashamed. I frankly do not know how anyone on that side of the House can sleep at night. Expanding gas production out past 2050 basically locks in catastrophic climate change. One of the lies that are perpetrated in this place, or these mistruths, is that Australia only has a small part to play when tackling climate change. Australia is one of the biggest exporters of fossil fuels in the world. In fact, the two countries that beat us are Saudi Arabia and Russia, which are hardly wonderful company to have.

So let's get this straight. The Labor Party is now going to spend public money expanding gas production out past 2050—gas production, by the way, that produces methane that is 80 times more potent in warming the planet than CO2. They let gas corporations get away with paying next to no tax. They're going to give them public money to do it. They roll over when the Labor resource minister gets written to by the CEO of Santos. It's incredible.

On taxes, by the way, we're about to have a federal budget, so let's talk about taxes for a second. Over a seven-year period, Santos made $28.9 billion in income. They paid an effective tax rate on that of 0.02 per cent. Eighty-two per cent of all the gas produced in Australia is exported overseas. So, really, what's remarkable about this—what is so destructive—is that they are pursuing a gas strategy that allows large multinational corporations, like Santos, Chevron and Woodside, to export enormous amounts of gas overseas, pay no tax on it, destroy the planet and hurt everyone other than the CEOs of Santos and Woodside. That's who the Labor Party is picking.

Let's think about Norway for a second. Some members of this place will say, 'It's very hard to tax gas corporations.' Norway manages it. In 2023, there was $209 billion earned in the Norwegian gas industry. They paid an effective tax rate of 63 per cent. In Australia, in the same year, gas corporations made $164 billion of revenue but only paid tax on that, plus royalties, at a rate of nine per cent. If those gas corporations in Australia paid the same tax rate as they did in Norway, in a single year the Australian government would have earned an extra $88.8 billion in revenue. That would fund putting dental into Medicare and completely solve the housing crisis by funding a mass construction of public housing. We could coordinate a freeze on rent increases. We could make university education free. We could wipe student debt. We could raise the poverty payments that the government forces people to live on, like JobSeeker, above the poverty line. We could do all of that. We could fundamentally improve people's lives and we could fund a transition plan out of coal and gas in the medium term.

Instead, this government is raising more money from student debt than they are from gas taxes, expanding gas production out past 2050 and approving coalmines that will be mining coal out to 2070—and expecting Australians to put up with it. Functionally what the Labor Party is doing in this place is acting as the political representative of Woodside, Santos and the entire gas industry. They're attempting to pull the wool over ordinary people's eyes by suggesting that somehow they care about other Australians out there.

But let's look at the evidence. There are record low taxes for gas corporations, which see Santos pay a lower percentage tax rate than a cleaner, a teacher or a nurse; they all pay a higher percentage tax rate than Santos does. There's public money to help Santos and Woodside do what they want to do—expand gas production and destroy the planet. At the end of all of this, what do we get? The world's scientists have said that warming is going to expand past 1½ degrees, and God only knows what's going to happen as warming surges past 2½ degrees and three degrees. And many members of this place won't have to be here to suffer the consequences. (Time expired)

Dr CHARLTON (Parramatta) (12:16): Let me be absolutely clear: this government is fully committed to climate action and net zero by 2050. This government is fully committed to 82 per cent renewables by 2030. Since we came to office, there's been a 25 per cent increase in renewables in the national energy market, and this has driven both total emissions and emissions intensity to all-time record lows. We've doubled the rate of approvals for energy projects and provided over $1 billion for homes and businesses to upgrade their energy efficiency.

But the Greens don't want to talk about that. The Greens don't want to talk about the enormous progress that has been made on climate change, during this Labor government, after 10 years of inactivity. Instead, they want to stand up and make a range of outrageous slurs against Labor and against Labor MPs. They want to stand there and make a series of outlandish claims. The reason for that is the Greens are fearful of one thing above all, and that is a sensible and practical path to address climate change. If we have a sensible and practical path to address climate change, we won't have the politics of outrage and we won't have the ability for them to make the perfect the enemy of the good. They are happy when the Liberals are in government, doing nothing on climate change, because it gives them the ability to rev up the outrage politics of climate change. That's why they're so annoyed about sensible, practical, middle-of-the-road climate change policies.

I saw this firsthand. In 2009 and 2010, I worked on the then Labor government's Carbon Pollution Reduction Scheme, which was a plan to put an emissions trading scheme into Australia for the first time, a plan that would have been world leading and would have made a massive difference to Australia over the last 15 years. Who opposed it? The Greens. And why did they oppose it? Because sensible, methodical progress on climate change is anathema to the politics that they want to run on this issue. Time and time again, the Greens are opposed to sensible and practical change. Time and time again, the Greens make the perfect the enemy of the good.

The reason for that is there is nothing worse for their political strategy than having positive progress, the kind of positive progress that this government has implemented over the last two years: making a real difference on renewables; making a real difference on transmission; signing up to ambitious targets; bringing the business sector and the rest of the community, including the unions, together around a national target that it can actually deliver; signing back up to our international commitments; and being a leader on the world stage in climate change. All of this is exactly what the Greens do not want—practical, sensible change. That's why they're trying to whip up outrage on this issue. That's why, first thing in after the break: bang, they're into the suspension of standing orders; bang, full of outrage; bang, lots of slurs against individual Labor MPs; bang, lots of outrage in the speech. All of it is because the thing they fear most is practical, real change that makes the politics of outrage irrelevant.

Well, we are going to continue on this path. We are going to continue to methodically and practically work through the challenges to address the climate crisis in this nation and around the world. We have seen more progress in two years than was able to be achieved in the last 10 years, more progress in two years than was able to be achieved in the entire period of Liberal government and, I'm sorry to say, more progress in two years than was achieved in the last Labor government, when we made the mistake of thinking the Greens were fair dinkum on climate change. We made that mistake, and look what happened. They wouldn't support an emissions-trading scheme in this country. How the world would have been different, how Australia would have been different, if they hadn't made the perfect the enemy of the good. They voted against the CPRS then, and that is exactly the tactic they have right now. That was a once-in-a-generation opportunity to address climate change in this country, to put us on a sensible path towards a clean energy future. The Greens took that off the table.

The member for Griffith stood up a moment ago and said, 'It's a mistake to think that Australia only has a small role to play in addressing global climate change.' We agree. We think Australia has a big role. That's why it's such a shame that back in 2010 the Greens stopped Australia from playing that role, from putting in a world-leading emissions-trading scheme. And that's why it's such a shame that they're trying to scupper the sensible, practical progress that has been made in Australia in the last two years. They don't want Australia playing that role on the world stage. They preferred it back when Australia was making no progress, under the Morrison government. In fact, the Leader of the Greens just a moment ago said, 'This government is worse than Scott Morrison.' Well, it's worse than Scott Morrison for him, friends, because, by doing sensible, practical things to address climate change, we're taking away the politics of outrage. He loved Scott Morrison. He loved the coal in the parliament. That enabled him to really rev up the outrage, to dial it up to 10.

That's why we're not seeing them come into this parliament and make any attacks on the Liberals' positions and we're not seeing them come in and support Labor's sensible positions. What we see instead is them pursuing the politics of outrage, because they don't want progress on climate change. Sensible, practical policies are their enemy, and they have always been their enemy. That's why they don't come in here and talk about the change that has occurred in Australia over the last 10 years and they don't attack Peter Dutton for his ridiculous, scandalous neglect on climate change. Australia is making progress, and they want to attack the government for that progress. What they would love is a world in which no progress was made, and they could go back to revving up the politics of outrage.

That is the difference. Labor is going to make practical, methodical change. We've made an enormous amount of progress in the last two years, and that is incredibly important to Australians. In my electorate, we face enormous consequences from climate change. In Parramatta, people are already paying the price with the impacts of climate change. Every summer, Parramatta gets almost 10 degrees hotter than the rest of Sydney. In 2019, one out of every eight days were above 35 degrees. And Parramatta is prone to catastrophic flooding—natural disasters that are getting worse and worse. In some of the published scenarios, up to 25 per cent of Parramatta could become a flood zone. That's why the people of Parramatta have been working to deliver a climate adaptation plan, a plan that addresses the local impacts of climate change and supports our progress in dealing with those impacts of climate change while at the same time the government gets on with mitigation.

Last week we delivered our Parramatta climate action plan, a plan supported by members of the community and community groups from across the electorate, distilling 137 community led recommendations into a plan that we can action over the next several years. That's sensible, methodical progress on climate change—real, practical action. At a local level, I'm so proud of the people of Parramatta for coming together on that plan. That practical, methodical plan is exactly the opposite of the politics of outrage that we see from the Greens as they come into this parliament.

For the first time in a decade we have a government taking climate change seriously. For the first time in a decade we have Australia back at the international table. For the first time in a decade we've got renewables going up. For the first time in a decade we have consensus from business groups, union groups and community groups on the need to address climate change. The people who cannot bear that consensus, the people who are completely opposed to that, who recognise it as the biggest threat to their political strategy are the Australian Greens political party. No wonder they've come into this House and expressed such outrage.

Ms CHANEY (Curtin) (12:26): I stand to support this motion condemning the Future Gas Strategy and calling on the environment minister and the resources minister to stop approving new coal and gas projects. I'm not into the politics of outrage, but I am fond of common sense. Gas does have a role in the transition. It is better than coal and it is a good firming fuel while we are working out the technology that we need to be truly net zero. We do need some gas during transition. It needs to be a fraction of the gas we're using today. We need to use as little gas as possible for as short a time as possible. This Future Gas Strategy is not a transition strategy; it is an expansion strategy.
Honourable members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The member for Moreton, the Leader of the Australian Greens and the member for Griffith, I'd like to hear the member for Curtin.

Ms CHANEY: This is not a transition strategy; it is an expansion strategy. We cannot expand gas all the way to net zero. It just does not make sense. In Western Australia at the moment we are experiencing a forest collapse event. There are dead trees all over my electorate that have not lasted through the summer, despite having lasted for 100 years before that.

We know that we need to reduce the use of gas. Gas is only part of the transition if it's replacing coal, not if it's replacing renewables. The danger is if we invest in gas projects now, hoping that the world will prefer our gas to our competitors' gas, we end up with too much gas and then gas becomes cheaper and it starts replacing renewables instead. We cannot use short-term issues to justify making bad long-term decisions.

This strategy is not presented in the context that it's as little as possible for as short a time as possible. It's not clear how this strategy fits with our international climate obligations, with driving reduction in demand for gas and with prioritising domestic needs over export. We export 90 per cent of our Western Australian gas offshore. We get little tax for that; the profits go overseas and it contributes to an unlivable planet. We are not sending a clear message to the investment community that we are serious about decarbonisation. It's a very mixed message, saying: 'We're expanding gas. We're open for business to 2050 and beyond. Oh, but we are also trying to incentivise renewables.' We need clear signals here.

Alan Kohler points out that this raises the question: what is the point of all the other work we're doing to reduce emissions when it is all undone by these huge gas projects? That is why this future gas strategy is not consistent with a livable planet; it is not consistent with Australia being committed to decarbonisation. I condemn it and I call on the environment minister and the resource minister to stop approving new coal and gas mines.

Dr RYAN (Kooyong) (12:29): April 2024 was the hottest April ever, globally; March 2024 was the hottest March ever, globally; and February 2024 was the same. The last 11 months have been the hottest ever. The Albanese government came to government promising that the climate wars were over, but what it's delivered to Australia with the Future Gas Strategy is a reopening of a wound which is a shame to this country. I don't know how members of the government can look at the children in their electorates, knowing what they are condemning them to, with the impact of fossil fuel emissions being apparent now. We're not kicking the can down the road; this is something with which our communities are already dealing.

The member for Parramatta has just spoken to us about the issues in Western Sydney and the heat islands in that part of the country, but so many parts of this country are dealing with the egregious effects of climate change now. The member for Curtin has already spoken to the same. There is no way that any member of the government who has looked at the science—who has seen members of the IPCC say on the weekend that 80 per cent of them believe that we will not avoid global warming to three degrees and beyond—can ignore that science. The Australian Academy of Science has said that global warming to three degrees and beyond is disastrous.

The SPEAKER: The time for debate has expired. The question is that the motion be agreed to. There being more than one voice calling for a division, in accordance with standing order 133 the division is deferred until after the discussion of the matter of public importance.
Debate adjourned.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (12:31): I present report No. 25 of the Standing Committee on Petitions.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 28 February 2024, 20 March 2024, 27 March 2024 and 22 April 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 81 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

PETITIONS
Presentation
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (12:31): by leave—I present the following 81 petitions:
Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

Cost of wieght loss medication is to high and many people can't afford it so go without even though they really need the help and being "obese" is considered very bad for your health and life exceptancy apparently
We therefore ask the House to make wieght loss medication covered by pbs and more accessible
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN5929)
Middle East

The decision to include Isreali Australians in the AVTOP whilst excluding Palestinian Australians is discrimination. By excluding Palestinian Australians from this payment, Services Australia is negating the genocide Palestinians are experiencing perpetrated by Isreal, as well as the continuously documented war crimes committed by Isreal against Palestinians.
We therefore ask the House to :
1. Call for an immediate and permanent ceasefire, and rescind all support for Isreal and the Isreali Defence Force (IDF), given their well documented crimes against humanity.
2. Include Palestinian Australians in the AVTOP program.
3. Make all members of the IDF ineligible for the AVTOP payment.
from 8,525 citizens (Petition No. EN5932)
Veterans

As it stands there are no statute time frames in relation to how quickly the Secretary shall forward documents to the Principal Member of the Veterans' Review Board in accordance with Veterans Entitlment Act (VEA) s137(4), with the Act stating, "as soon as practicable"...

Under the Act there is a circumstance where by the Secretary can conduct a further investigation, however this is only permissible where the Veteran Applicant furnished comments in relation to the 137(1)(a) relevant evidence report...

Modern document storage and retrieval practices are such that all the relevant information is instantly available, and in instances where the Veteran provides no 137(3) "comments", or where no further investigation will be conducted it seems appropriate that a statute time frame for forwarding all the relevant documents to the VRB be introduced into the VEA.

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes to cause an amendment to the VEA that introduces a statute time frame of not more than seven days in instances where the Veteran provides no 137(3) comments, or where no further investigation will be conducted.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN5934)
Veterans

When the Veterans Entitlement Act 1986 (VEA) was drafted, document storage was physical and hard copy, and it was appropriate that 6 weeks be allocated for the Secretary to cause the preparation, and servicing of reports on the Veteran in accordance with VEA s137(1) obligations…

Contemporary DVA soft (electronic) document storage practices require that 137(1) "evidence" now be labelled and filed by the decision maker at the time the determination is made. The result being the "evidence" which conforms with 137(1)(a) can be instantly identified and retrieved, and 137 reports can be prepared and forwarded within a few hours. And few days in the rare instance where the applicant requires a hard copy…

It is widely acknowledged that decision review is lengthy, and amending the 137(1) time frame for preparing and forwarding these reports to reflect the management, storage and retrieval of documents in an electronic era will reduce decision review by many weeks. All at no cost to the Veteran or Commonwealth…

An amendment as outlined below will not only cause for the VRB to commence its obligations five weeks earlier, but on receipt of the VEA s148(1) "review notice", the Repatriation Commission will be able to commence any VEA s31 (own motion) review it deems appropriate five weeks sooner than is currently possible.
We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes to cause an amendment to the VEA that amends the 137(1) time frame to seven days.
from 57 citizens (Petition No. EN5935)
Middle East

Palestinian people are being subject to a genocide as we speak, the most documented genocide that's unfolding before our eyes and we can see torn apart bodies of kids everyday on our smartphones. There is severe food and water shortage and people are eating grass to survive. In this moment of severe vulnerability, Israel has accused UNRWA of terrorism without providing any proof. UNRWA is the last aid provider which is standing between Palestinian people and a famine. Our very own foreign minister Penny Wong admitted that Australia dont have any facts regarding the UNRWA allegations. But Australia was quick to disconnect funding to UNRWA based on just allegations. On the other hand, ICJ ruled that there is a plausible genocide being committed by Israel, based on court hearings and real, hard evidence. But Australia remains silent in supporting the ICJ of the oppressed side.

Its clear, Australia is taking side with the oppressor. Also, Australian politicians are sending a clear message to the multi-cultural community that some lives are considered cheap, which is harmful for the long run for social cohesion.
We therefore ask the House to take action for resuming UNRWA funding and cut ties with Israel until it stops the genocidal activities on Palestinians.
from 351 citizens (Petition No. EN5938)
Cybercrime

As our lives become increasingly dependent upon online interactions and communication, so too increases our risk of online abuse and illegal activity stemming from predatory behaviour. Areas that commonly receive attention and action are fraudulent online activity and phishing scams. However of particular concern is the rise in people using online platforms to perpetrate domestic violence including abuse, control and stalking behaviour. Additionally, predatory child exploitation and abuse crimes are occurring with increasing frequency. There are many loopholes within our state and national frameworks that render current laws essentially non-enforceable, and it is near-impossible for criminals to be successfully charged with their cyber crimes. The issues are multifaceted but it is pertinent that we address them to prevent an exponential rise in these effectively unpunishable crimes, and the damage caused to victims as a result.

We therefore ask the House to create a national framework and revise current laws, in order to hold criminals accountable, and ensure that online platforms co-operate with law enforcement. Circumstantial evidence needs to be held in higher regard for cybercrime, including DV related cybercrime and online crimes involving children. The reality is that people commit these crimes in private, and even when the IP address is traceable, the respondent can avoid prosecution by saying they weren't in possession of that device at that time. We ask that Australia takes this stand to improve online safety for our citizens, and protect victims, instead of encouraging this new uprising in safeguarded criminals.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN5939)
E-Cigarettes and Vaping Products

The coming March 1st re-usable vape bans will only harm those who have successfully used vapes to quit cigarettes, as someone who smoked for many years, vapes were instrumental to me quitting, and working my way from a high nicotine liquid, to what I am now—nicotine free.

With a user's nicotine addiction gone, the habit may remain as a source of comfort and a way to alleviate stress without relapsing with nicotine. The government's plan to unilaterally ban nicotine free liquids will ultimately hurt those who used vapes the right way, not kids, not illegal users, but legal adults making a choice to use a product that doesn't harm them.

The government's solution to make vapes available through pharmacies is insulting, and damaging to those who vape as a habit, NOT for nicotine use. The vapes supplied by pharmacies are also ludicrously high in nicotine, and will directly funnel those who have successfully kicked nicotine back into the arms of addiction.

We therefore ask the House to revise the March 1st implementation of federal vape laws, and in tandem with experts devise a common sense implementation to the banning of nicotine free, reusable vape liquids.
from 58 citizens (Petition No. EN5940)
Skilled Migration Program
Save future talent and reconsider pending 476 visa applications.

We therefore ask the House to urgently appeal for a reconsideration of the decision to capped SC 476 visa applications. It is imperative to uphold the principles of fairness and ensure that the aspirations of countless individuals, who have invested time and effort in their applications, are not unjustly quashed. We (Pakistani Community in Australia-PCIA) advocate for policies that embrace and encourage the entry of skilled individuals, enriching our communities and contributing to the nation's prosperity.
from 1,163 citizens (Petition No. EN5942)
Telecommunications

Since the haphazard billion dollar rollout of the NBN across Australia, there have been ongoing issues with Telstra comminications services, particularly in regional areas and for those who cannot get NBN. This is effecting the safety of communitys in emergency situation, it hinders business productivity and halts customers from being a communite with friends, family, business associates and others. The level of disfunction in the service (although this can be locality or landscape specific) is very high.
We therefore ask the House to conduct a nationwide independant review of Telstra services, with specific regard to the productivity and effectiveness of its services for all Australians.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN5943)
Passenger Rail Industry

Regional South Australia is currently facing a significant lack of public transport options, particularly in the realm of passenger rail services. With the cessation of Australian National Railways Commission operations in 1998, South Australia's regional rail network has suffered, leading to decreased connectivity, economic stagnation, and environmental concerns. The absence of viable rail services has placed undue burdens on residents, hindering access to essential services, limiting employment opportunities, and impeding regional growth.

We therefore ask the House to acknowledge the vital role of regional passenger rail in fostering economic prosperity, enhancing social cohesion, and mitigating environmental impacts. We urge the Federal Government to collaborate with the South Australian Government to facilitate the repair and revitalisation of regional passenger rail infrastructure. This includes providing financial assistance, technical expertise, and policy support to re-establish and modernise regional rail services, ensuring sustainable and equitable transportation options for all Australians. By prioritising the restoration of regional passenger rail, the Federal Government can demonstrate its commitment to fostering inclusive development, reducing carbon emissions, and supporting the prosperity of regional communities. Furthermore, we urge the House to conduct a comprehensive review of national rail policies and funding mechanisms to address systemic challenges hindering the viability of regional passenger rail services across Australia. By implementing supportive regulatory frameworks and investing in innovative solutions, the Federal Government can ensure the long-term sustainability and accessibility of regional rail networks, fulfilling its duty to facilitate equitable transportation infrastructure for all Australians.
from 15 citizens (Petition No. EN5945)
Rail Industry

The current state of Australia's rail infrastructure hampers efficiency and competitiveness in transportation, negatively impacting economic growth and sustainability. Key issues include inadequate speed limits and single-track limitations, hindering both passenger and freight services.

We therefore ask the House to instruct the Australian Rail Track Corporation (ARTC) to review and update speed limits nationwide. Specifically, initially increase the minimum average passenger train speed to 160km/h and raise the freight speed limit to 120-130km/h while ensuring safety standards are maintained with the intent of improving speeds further in the future.

Allocate funding for the investigation and implementation of double-track upgrades, starting from all mainland capital cities, to alleviate congestion, reduce delays, and enhance efficiency with a goal to connect all mainland Capitals with double track.
Investigate how the Tasmanian rail network can integrate with the mainland network/s.
Prioritise investment in modernising rail infrastructure to enhance safety, efficiency, and competitiveness in Australia's transportation network.
We believe these measures will promote economic growth, environmental sustainability, and improve overall quality of life for Australians.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN5946)
Racism

We, the undersigned, express our grave concerns about the rising incidents of antisemitism in Australia. Antisemitism affects everyone, as it's the leading indicator of a lack of social cohesion, which in turn imperils the moral destiny of our nation.
We therefore ask the House to condemn all party leaders to condemn antisemitism unequivocally and publicly; (all party leaders to do so after significant antisemitic acts).

Law enforcement agencies at the Federal and State levels to fully enforce laws against hate symbols, speech and threats of violence, ensuring the safety of every individual; (tracked by police confidence in their ability to enforce laws).
Take legislative measures to protect and uphold the safety and rights of the Jewish community to include death chants; (tracked by % antisemitic incidents investigated that are prosecuted).

Implement relevant training programs for every government employee, within our cultural institutions, education systems, and faith communities, to raise awareness about antisemitism, and to foster an environment of understanding and tolerance; (tracked by % of government employees who pass antisemitic face-to-face training every 2 years, funding tied to % target).
Outlaw political activism within the education system, and all government institutions (tracked by number of activism incidents that call for the boycott of democratic nations that combat terrorism);
By standing against antisemitism, we can preserve Australia's global standing as one of the safest countries in the world, where every individual is treated with dignity and respect.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN5947)
Migration

We urge the House of Representatives to acknowledge the contributions made by temporary visa workers during the crippling COVID pandemic by granting permanent residency to those who stayed and contributed to Australia's economy.

The pandemic was unprecedented, and Australia was not spared. Our loyalty during this time was invaluable to our employers and the Government. We undoubtedly contributed, and continue to contribute to Australia's economy. Paying rent over multiple years to Australian homeowners, dutifully paying our taxes, fulfilling obligations and visa requirements that ensure we are no burden on the Government, Health or Education departments.

The Hon Clare O'Neil announced in April 2023 "…by the end of 2023, all temporary skilled workers will have a pathway to permanent residency". Changes implemented thus far is not helping 482 medium-term stream temporary workers that are bouncing from one 482 visa to another.
The taxes and FIRB approvals, and higher deposits required by banks, makes owning our own property simply unrealistic. We are unable to provide security for our own families.
Being permanently temporary is a constant threat of uncertainty hanging over us.

We therefore ask the House to action our request of granting permanent residency to all temporary visa holders who stayed, worked and contributed to Australia during the pandemic—without imposing additional financial costs to us or our employers.
We are not requesting another "pathway to PR". Our commitment and sacrifices made during Australia's time of need warrant this just recognition.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. EN5950)
Middle East

We urgently petition the House to address the unlawful occupation of Palestinian land by citizens of Israel, particularly Australian dual citizens. Violations of international law necessitate immediate action.

The actions of Australian citizens with dual Israeli citizenship that reside or work on occupied Palestinian land are not only in contravention of international law but also potentially violate the Commonwealth Criminal Code. Specifically, Division 268 of the Criminal Code outlines numerous war crimes offences, which include the unlawful deportation or transfer of population from occupied territories.

Furthermore, Division 268 also codifies various acts that constitute Crimes Against Humanity; these include acts committed as part of a widespread or systematic attack directed against any civilian population, including forcible transfers of population, apartheid, persecution, and other inhumane acts.
We therefore ask the House to :

1. Investigate and prosecute Australian citizens who are involved in Israel's illegal settlement enterprise or in the displacement of Palestinian people in accordance with the Commonwealth Criminal Code.

2. Implement measures to prevent Australian companies or individuals from engaging in activities that support or benefit from the illegal occupation of Palestinian land, including Israel's illegal settlement enterprise, consistent with Australia's commitment to upholding international law.

3. Advocate for the immediate cessation of illegal settlement activities and the restoration of Palestinian people's rights and sovereignty over their ancestral lands through diplomatic channels and international cooperation.

In the pursuit of justice, accountability, and respect for human rights, we urge the House to prioritise the enforcement of domestic laws and international legal standards to address these egregious violations.
from 1,219 citizens (Petition No. EN5954)
Ukraine

We have all noticed the increase in aggression from non western nation states over the last ten years. We can not afford for Ukraine to become another 'forever war', constantly draining our resources, and drawing attention away from the real dangers closer to our borders.

The Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas has proposed a plan, for the members of the Ramstein Group, (a group of western states which support Ukraine, which Australia is a member of), to commit to spending 0.25% of yearly GDP for military aid to Ukraine. According to the proposed plan, this would raise 120 billion Euros by 2027, allowing Ukraine certainty of funding for future developments, reducing the reliance on the big economies of the USA, UK, Germany and France, all of which seem to have slowed or even totally halted their aid to Ukraine, (with the notable exception of the UK).

The most important reason for this aid, would be to show Putin that through all the international turmoil, the West is still united, and to bring about an earlier end to this conflict, saving thousands of lives.
We therefore ask the House to put forward a motion for Australia to join with Estonia in committing to spend .25% of GDP on aid to Ukraine until 2027, and hasten the end of this war.
from 23 citizens (Petition No. EN5955)
Housing

In the midst of a cost of living crisis and unprecedented rise in interest rates, mortgage holders (particularly those that have recently brought into the market) have been decimated by the terrible decision of the political class and the RBA. They made the decisions and you pay the price. Allowing people to access their super to pay off or pay down their mortgage will slash their interest payments (if not eliminate them), bring much need funds back into the household budget, while also giving back a sense of control to peoples lives. When household ownership is a key indicator to the quality of one's retirement, it makes zero sense to pay 10s of thousands in interest now, when you won't see those returns by retirement and may even be in the situation where you still need to use your super to pay off the house. This would only apply to the first home owners. Investors or those with multiple properties would not be able to access their super, even if they reside in the house that still has a mortgage over it. If the government of the day was serious about helping people now this would be a common sense and immediate impact they can make without having to print money and further fuel inflation—super is your money you worked for!
We therefore ask the House to implement legalisation that will allow first home owners to access their super to pay down or off their mortgage.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN5957)
Parliamentary Standards
Family groups who become politicians can manipulate what they want to benefit the family
We therefore ask the House to make laws that only one family member can be in politics a politician at any one time
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5959)
Banking and Financial Services
1. BANKS REFUSING TO SUPPLY CASH AT BRANCHES
2. SOME BANKS ONLY SUPPLYING CASH TO THIER CUSTOMERS AND REFUSING OTHER CUSTOMERS
3. CONTINUAL THREATS THAT CASH WILL NOT EXIST IN THE FUTURE
4. BUISNESSES REFUSING TO ACCEPT CASH FOR GOODS
5. MANY AUSTRALIANS PREFER TO HAVE CASH IN THIER HANDS
6. IN TIMES OF TROUBLE I.E. COMPUTERS DOWN, CYBER ATTACKES, CASH IS A PREFERRED CURRENCY
7. MANY AUSTRALIANS SEE CASH ON HAND AS A METHOD OF THEIR INDEPENDENCE
8. LACK OF GOVERNMENT INTERVENTION AND BUISNESS ACTIONS ARE FORCING THE DEMISE OF CASH

We therefore ask the House to acknowledge and legislate that money i.e. cash in the form of notes and coins will NEVER be withdrawn from society and be left in circulation and be a requirement of the Banking system to supply same and exchange same to citizens whether they are account holders or not as part of a license. Further that Banks cease closing any further branches and the House investigate a formula calculated against major banks profits to main existing branches and open up others to afford services to all citizens. It is unacceptable to have Bank closures continuing with the public having to accept declining services to bolster the Banks profits.
When all fails, computers or cyber attacks follows, recessions, depressions, the Government then has sufficient cash in the system for an economy to continue with a cash "Back up System".
from 866 citizens (Petition No. EN5960)
Veterans

On 25 July 2023 an application was made to the Repatriation Medical Authority (Authority) to review the contents of the Tooth Wear Statement of Principles (SoPs). In support of that application, the Authority was provided sound medical-scientific evidence by way of peer reviewed paper by Wetselaar (2020), Diagnosing tooth wear, a new taxonomy based on the revised version of the Tooth Wear Evaluation System…

The Authority refused to review the SoPs on the basis, "Wetselaar does not, in the opinion of the Authority, provide information which would justify a review of the tooth wear SoPs." Under the Veterans' Entitlement Act there is no entitlement for the applicant to appeal this decision…

Despite this, Professor Terence Campbell, Chairperson of the Authority at 22 in his decision, stated, "Although not a reason for its decision, the Authority did note that where tooth wear is mild, a claim can be made to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for treatment, where it will be assessed on its merits as a Non SoP condition."…
Great clarity will be provided to those Veterans with mild tooth wear if a fourth note were added to 6(2) of the Tooth Wear SoPs reflective of what Professor Campbell stated in his decision…

We therefore ask the House to initiate such processes as to cause such change in the SoPs which reflect what Professor Campbell has stated at 22 in his decision not to investigate the Tooth wear SoPs.
from 50 citizens (Petition No. EN5961)
Banking and Financial Services

Based upon recent information, Morgage Interest Rates are not included in the CPI basket of goods, with people who have a mortgage inflation ineffectively being 7% as against people with no mortgage having an effective rate of 3%. Clearly high interest rates are driving Inflation.

With the RBA not making a profit and the Big 4 Banks making Super Profits, the RBA providing the Big 4 Banks free money which was then deposited into the TFF to finally receive a 4.45% on that free money.
The Australian Public should be fully informed of the Multinational Majority owners of the Big 4 Banks
We therefore ask the House to legislate the following

1. ACCC to provide Quarterly publications on all media, advice since 2008 indicating the share holdings of each of the Big 4 Banks and the interconnection (eg The percentage of each Multinational in each of the Big 4 Banks) and how collusion is evaded.
2.All Multinationals taxed 5% on the turnover without deductions based upon the percentage owned.
3.Allow Australian Industry Super to have the majority share of the Big 4 Banks to allow the Super profits to be forwarded to members rather than overseas.
4. Make Australia Post a Bank complete with a lending arm as they are facilitating the Big 4 Bank Closures work load and provide the required Competition.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN5963)
Nicotine Dependence

According to the Therapeutic Goods Administration Oral Nicotine pouches are restricted under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 and require strict approval to obtain in australia. While nicotine is a highly addictive substance, nicotine pouches are far safer then the alternatives of smoking and vaping as they only contain food acids and stabilizer with the addition of nicotine. The current laws suppress the rights of australians who seek to quite smoking for a safer alternative that research shows is not nearly as damaging to the body as smoking. I ask for change as an australian who would like to see these alternatives, in addition laws can be created surrounding Oral Nicotine Pouches to restrict the sale to minors.

We therefore ask the House to review the current laws around the use of Oral Nicotine Pouches and amend the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 so they are no longer heavily restricted. with safer alternatives to smoking and vaping such as nicotine pouch it is clear that the house should please consider the approval of Oral Nicotine Pouches for the Australian nicotine market. Oral Nictotine pouches being safer and a better alternative can also help support small local business that have been affected due to the 2024 vape ban.
from 35 citizens (Petition No. EN5964)
Arts and Culture

The petition urgently requests government action to safeguard Australia's music and arts sector, currently in crisis. Highlighting the sector's $111.7 billion annual economic contribution, it faces jeopardy from event cancellations, threatening artists' livelihoods and cultural vibrancy. Advocating for significant government support, the petition suggests a $7 billion investment per state or territory for the arts, alongside direct funding, tax incentives, educational initiatives, and a $350 million emergency fund for live music venues. It calls on Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and key officials for genuine commitment towards arts, emphasizing mental health and cultural heritage. The proposal includes forming specialized bodies and a Royal Commission to strategize the industry's recovery and growth.
We therefore ask the House to consider

1. Immediate Financial Support: A transformative $7 billion allocation for the arts per state or territory, plus a $350 million emergency fund for venues, and a broader package for the music industry.
2. Policy Enhancements: Boost funding, subsidies, tax incentives, and educational programs. Promote diversity and inclusivity.
3. Strategic Development: Craft a national arts strategy with stakeholders, establish specialized bodies, and propose a Royal Commission for 2024.
from 27 citizens (Petition No. EN5966)
Banking and Financial Services
Banks and businesses are going cashless. This is causing pain to people because they know charge more money on top of prices

We therefore ask the House to investigate the reason why banks and businesses are going cashless. Citizens of Australia didn't ask banks or businesses to go cashless why do they feel the need to charge people more money to cover card charges . If everyone goes cashless banks and businesses can hold citizens to pay any amount they want .banks can hold customers accounts to justify what they spend there money on before banks release you money .
from 135 citizens (Petition No. EN5967)
Interest Rates
Stop the rise in interest rates.
Banks are recording their highest profits in 29 years
Consumers are paying the price and doing it tough
The pressure of the interest hikes are forcing families into financial hardship.

We therefore ask the House to address the concern regarding the current financial challenges faced by individuals and families across our nation, exacerbated by the unprecedented increase in interest rates imposed by banks.

The recent surge in interest rates has led to an overwhelming burden on individuals and families, manifesting in severe stress, anxiety, and financial instability. Many of us find ourselves struggling to meet basic needs such as food, fuel, and everyday expenses due to the exorbitant costs imposed by these rate hikes. It is distressing to note that while individuals are grappling with financial hardship, banks continue to report record-breaking profits, marking their highest earnings in 29 years.

This dire situation calls for urgent attention and intervention from our legislative bodies. We cannot stand idly by as the well-being and mental health of our citizens are jeopardized by the unchecked actions of financial institutions. There is a pressing need for transparency and accountability regarding the rationale behind allowing such drastic increases in interest rates within a short span of time.

We implore the House to conduct a thorough investigation into the factors contributing to the escalation of interest rates and the adverse impact on individuals and families nationwide. Our collective well-being and financial security depend on swift and decisive action to address this pressing issue.
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN5969)
Pakistan: General Election

Concerned about the meeting between the Australian High Commissioner in Pakistan and Maryam Nawaz Sharif amidst heavily rigged recent elections. This raises questions about the Australian government's stance on the legitimacy of the election results. Transparency and fairness must be upheld.

The Australian government must not legitimize this rigged election, where 80% of Pakistanis voted for Imran Khan and his party, while Maryam and her party allegedly manipulated the mandate with the help of the establishment, primarily Army Chief Asim Munir. Australia claims to uphold democratic values globally; however, their High Commissioner meeting with Maryam Nawaz raises concerns, especially amid global criticism of pre and post-poll rigging in the 2024 Pakistan election.
We therefore ask the House to clear their stance on Pakistan's rigged election and provide substantiation on this meeting.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5970)
Nuclear Energy

Nuclear power is a low-carbon energy source, presenting a viable solution to combatting climate change by significantly reducing our greenhouse gas emissions. Embracing nuclear power enhances our energy security by providing a stable and reliable energy supply, thus reducing our dependence on volatile global energy markets. The economic benefits are substantial, with the potential for job creation, technological innovation, and increased investments in the nuclear energy sector contributing to overall economic growth. Additionally, the adoption of nuclear power positions Australia as a leader in nuclear science and engineering, fostering technological advancements with applications across various industries. Stringent safety standards and regulations ensure the secure operation of modern nuclear power plants, addressing concerns about safety. I urge a comprehensive evaluation of the feasibility of nuclear power in Australia, emphasizing the potential environmental, economic, and technological advantages that this energy source could bring to our nation.

We therefore ask the House to House to swiftly consider implementing nuclear power in Australia. Embracing this low-carbon solution not only addresses climate concerns and enhances energy security but also holds the potential for economic growth and technological leadership. With modern safety standards in place, we request a prompt and comprehensive evaluation, involving experts and the public, to guide decisions aligned with Australia's commitment to a sustainable future. Your expedited attention to this matter is crucial for securing a cleaner, more resilient energy landscape for our nation.
from 78 citizens (Petition No. EN5972)
Genetically Modified Organisms
The Gene Technology Regulator should take into account intellectual property (Plant Breeder Right) issues when approving a Genetically Modified Organism.

Say for instance in food crops; if an Organic crop is surrounded by Genetically Modified crops, the seed stock could become contaminated, and then, inadvertently growing a IP protected Genetically Modified crop could expose the grower to legal action.
The Regulator in the Risk Assessment only needs to take into account:
(2) In preparing the risk management plan, the Regulator must take into account the following:
(a) the means of managing any risks posed by those dealings in such a way as to protect:
(i) the health and safety of people; and
(ii) the environment;

In the recent DIR 199, the Regulator responded to 94 mentions of commercial issues by stating "The commercial motives of biotechnology companies are outside the scope of responsibility of the Regulator."
Parliament must act, to protect organic farms, and to prevent the loss of diversity in the seed stock by domination of Genetically Modified variants.

We therefore ask the House to amend the Gene Technology Act 2000 to force the Regulator to look at commercial and IP issues to protect organic and non organic growers from unforeseen intellectual property issues.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5973)
Climate Change

This world is changing and we need to stop it. We are loosing animals that are vital for the ecosystem. if the eco system is gone so are we. We are using factories,cars and fossil fuels and the government wants to change it by 2040. By 2040 this world would have change to much and everything would be gone. We need an earlier date to save the things around us.
We therefore ask the House to change the date on going full electric and change announce climate to the world. This world is changing and I want my future to be as bright as my past.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN5974)
European Union
The EU is incompetent to lay down the conditions governing entry into and legal residence in a Member or Partner State. evidenced in Australia and EU Member States.
This incompetency endangers cultural stability in Australia.
The expectation of the European Union partnership for Australia to share and deplete Australian resources is not consistent with Australian goals.
Australia's partnership with the European Union is detrimental to Australian Culture.
Australian partnership with the European Union has no benefit for Australian Citizens.
Australian People do not agree that the European Union can expect Australia to accept immigration. Australian Citizens do not accept an immigration quota being dictated to us.
Australian People want immigration to completely cease until all Australian Citizens are fed, housed and employed.

Australians speak with a unique sound, being the English language with an Aboriginal accent, and thus Australians reasonably and respectfully request that foreign tongues be kept out of Australia to enable Australians to preserve Our identity and Our resources for Our selves and Our descendants.
We pray the House will cease all immigration, and not reconsider it's acceptance for a minimum of 12 years.
We therefore ask the House to put Australian Citizens first in all matters. and
cease Australia's Partnership with the European Union, and
cease all immigration for a minimum or 12 years.
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN5976)
Electoral Roll
The right of Australian Citizens to choose the directions that Australia takes in any and all matters is diminished by allowing foreigners to vote in Our Country.
We therefore ask the House to legislate to allow only Australian Citizens the right to vote in Australia, and
not allow non-Australian Citizens to vote in any Australian elections.
from 33 citizens (Petition No. EN5977)
Workplace Safety

Exposure to secondhand smoke (SHS) has been consistently identified as a public health hazard and cause of disease for many hospitality workers ex: ( non smokers hospitality employees in the casino gaming areas in Australia).
As a hospitality employees, and a non smoker , we need to support the SHS of the customers at work inside the gaming area.

We therefore ask the House to find a way that can help with the smoke free work environment for non smoking employees in the casino gaming areas, or to create designated smoking rooms only for the smoking customers, prior to enter the gaming room.
from four citizens (Petition No. EN5978)
Competition Policy: Bookstores

Independent bookshops in Australia are struggling. Not because people don't read anymore, but because international, online retailers and large chain stores are discounting new release books in Australia. While this may seem good for customers, it puts comptetitors (bookshops) out of business, reducing competition in the long run.

Why does that matter? Local bookstores employ locals, spend income in other local businesses, provide services to the community like author events and book clubs and promote local, diverse, Australian and first time authors. We curate our collections for our communities and customers. We LOVE books and authors.

Booksellers need a level playing field. We can't sell new books when other retailers get the same books on release and sell them at 50% off RRP. We pay MORE than 50% to publishers as small businesses.
Fixed-price laws apply in many countries and it works. If we value the arts, Australian literature and writers, small business and local bookshops we need to do this.
How it works—a publisher sets the price a book can be sold at for a set time after publication. That price applies to every bookseller in the country, large or small, and to books being sold online.

"Without independent bookstores, there is effectively little market for Australian literature and no future for Australian writers," Richard Flanagan to Raymond Bonner in The Age/SMH 10 Feb 2024—If you love discount books, you don't love their authors.
We therefore ask the House to Legislate fixed-price laws for books In Australia.
from 624 citizens (Petition No. EN5979)
Public Libraries

Children in Australian libraries face exposure to explicit content, featuring graphic depictions of sexual acts in both text and enticing illustrations. Alarming is the absence of age restrictions and bypassing of the Classification Review Board's scrutiny, violating the Classification Act of 1995. Public Service Commissioner Peter Woolcott's October 25th, 2022, Child Safety Statement underscores a zero-tolerance stance on child abuse. The pervasive explicit materials can be seen as a form of child grooming, jeopardizing children's safety. Unlike adults, children lack the developed filter to discern inappropriate content and may succumb to peer pressure. The petition calls for these explicit publications to be confined to restricted areas, safeguarding children from unrestricted access.

We therefore ask the House to to take immediate action, proposing comprehensive measures for handling sexually explicit publications in public and school libraries. Firstly, explicit materials should be removed from open display, accessible only upon request and confined to restricted areas. Minors seeking such content must be accompanied by a parent or guardian. The definition of sexually explicit publications is detailed, encompassing various forms of explicit content. Additionally, legally restricted publications should be entirely removed from library catalogs. A thorough audit of libraries for "Submittable Publications" is recommended, with any meeting the criteria sent for classification review. Emphasizing consistent classification across formats, the petition calls for a proactive approach to protect children from explicit content.
from 2,102 citizens (Petition No. EN5982)

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

p.span: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

As someone who has witnessed the operations of the Shincheonji Church, I am deeply concerned about its activities in Australia. Founded in 1984 by Lee Man-hee, this group claims that Lee is the one true pastor prophesied to appear at end times. In Australia, they have been actively targeting young Christians from regular churches and universities by inviting them to Bible Studies where they indoctrinate participants with their unorthodox teachings.

Once a person joins this group, they are strongly encouraged to sever ties with friends and family members so that the group becomes their sole source of companionship. This isolation technique is a common characteristic of cult-like organizations and can have severe psychological effects on individuals.

We therefore ask the House to take action against these harmful practices which exploit vulnerable individuals under the guise of religious freedom. We need legislation or enforcement that protects our citizens from being manipulated by such groups.
from 651 citizens (Petition No. EN5983)
Nuclear Energy

So Australian taxpayers retain the benefits of Australian government funding of businesses and their retention of investment and technology development in Australia's fusion energy industry on Australian shores. Allow the development of Fusion energy in Australia and the building of demonstration fusion power plants to show commercial viability so Australia can participate in this international growth industry.

We therefore ask the House to amend any legislation concerning the use of plasma fusion energy development in line with international regulations similar to the US NRC Decision to separate Fusion Energy Regulation from its Nuclear regulation and as the UK has also done and continued with the management of fusion in its environment legislation outside the nuclear agency and to develop a new regulatory framework to cater for this.
from eight citizens (Petition No. EN5984)
Renewable Energy
Example for classroom.

We as a school community feel strongly about the issue of sea ice continuously disappearing in the Antarctic. This issue has recently been brought to the attention of our class and we feel strongly that this issue needs to be addressed and for this concern to be focused on by the Federal Government. This issue involves the continuous use of fossil fuels and our governments plans to continue developing coal mines like Adani has unfortunately contributed to this.

In the last 8 years, the levels of sea ice has shown a decrease in the natural resurgence during the winter months. This trend may be a natural variation and in the next couple of years it may show some regularity in its seasons. This is very unlikely and other examples of climate change have indicated a need for this issue to be at the forefront of our governments attention. With the rise in extreme weather events in this country, the need for renewable energy needs to be at the forefront of our innovation. We believe this concern needs to be addressed by the Federal government and a change in policy needs to occur for this issue to be resolved.

We therefore ask the House to look into the current policies in place for carbon emissions particularly for large companies and outline a process for fazing out coal mines for a more renewable source of energy.
from three citizens (Petition No. EN5985)
Tertiary Education: Unpaid Clinical Placement

Workforce planning anticipates a future nursing workforce deficit of 123,000 nurses by 2030. Under current clinical placement arrangements, students complete between 800 and 1200 hours of unpaid clinical placement as a mandatory component in the Bachelor of Nursing. Although unpaid work experience is illegal in Australia, students are required to complete upwards of 800 hours of unpaid work for educational purposes.

Students completing clinical placement experience significant financial hardship, as they either need to complete paid work outside of full time clinical placement and risk patient safety, or not earn an income for several weeks. Healthcare students struggle to afford rent, travel, and food costs during unpaid clinical placement and there is an increased reliance on emergency and food relief organisations. Financial hardships including increased cost of living, slow wage growth, and HECS debt indexing at 7.1% additionally impact students, and is another barrier impacting healthcare students during unpaid clinical placements. This barrier is preventing students from completing healthcare qualifications, and causing students to enter the workforce in significant debt.

We therefore ask the House to address the financial inequalities experienced by healthcare students and end unpaid clinical placements. We kindly request for the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP) debt reduction program to be expanded to include all health workers completing unpaid clinical placements. Waiving the HECS debts of healthcare workers recognises the unpaid morning, afternoon, and night shift contributions made by healthcare students, and ensures that the system that enables unpaid clinical placement is retired.
from 2,332 citizens (Petition No. EN5988)
National Disability Insurance Scheme

The role of plan management is under threat. Plan managers are a legislated role supporting National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) Participants by reducing their administrative burden. Almost 400,000 Participants (62%) choose to use a plan manager to handle the payment of $19.2b/yr (50%) for their supports. Of that amount, plan managers only receive $511mil/yr, but the work they do is priceless.

Plan management provides an additional level of independent accountability and visibility for taxpayers' funds for a low fixed fee (<2.0%). This essential financial oversight is subject to registration standards, pricing limits, and audits, with the highest scrutiny of all fund management methods.

The NDIS Review recommends the removal of plan management and plan managers. Instead, recommending the introduction of a digital payments platform, and combining multiple support roles into one 'system navigator' role. This decision will directly affect Participants as well as their nominees and carers, forcing them to take on the additional administrative burden and reducing their support, regardless of their choice or capabilities.

Plan Management is about so much more than paying the bills. Ironically, even the NDIS Review Final Report says "Plan Managers still have an important role to play in supporting prevention, detection, and response to non-compliance, sharp practice, and fraud."
We therefore ask the House to ensure the legislated role of plan managers continues to remain a choice for Participants.
Protect plan managers as a method of accountability for taxpayers' funds, and protect the Participants' choice and control of support.
from 4,172 citizens (Petition No. EN5993)
Skilled Migration Program
Work sponsorship visa were reduced from 3 years to 2 years. Why can't state sponsorship visas 491 / 494 also not be reduced to 2 years, to be able to apply for 191 PR
We therefore ask the House to reduce the 3 year requirement to 2 years and then be able to apply for 191 visa.
from 48 citizens (Petition No. EN5994)
National Security
The head of ASIO stated that a former politician had sold out Australia to a foreign intelligence service.
Australians deserve to know who this person is, and that they have been held accountable for their actions.
We therefore ask the House to identify, by name and on the public record, the former politician investigated or under investigation for disclosing information to a foreign intelligence service.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN5996)
Defence Procurement
Elbit Systems was recently awarded an almost $1bn contract to supply components for new fighting vehicles for the Australian Government.

Elbit Systems is one of the most complicit companies in Israeli war crimes and the ongoing genocide in Gaza, with deep links to the IDF and a history of advertising it's products as battle-tested on Palestinians.

In 2021 the ADF removed all Elbit Systems products over security concerns; now we ask that this company is removed from the ADF over human rights and moral concerns. Many allies around the world, including Japan, have banned Elbit Systems as a supplier, and we ask that the Australian Government does the same. We do not want to be complicit in the genocide and illegal settlement of Palestine through almost $1bn of Australian money.
From Senator Shoebridge in parliament -

"The Albanese government is also paying Israeli defence contractor Elbit Systems to construct turrets... It's the same Elbit Systems that, only a few years ago, had to be stripped from Australian military equipment for fears it was stealing data covertly. It's the same Elbit Systems that proudly states on its website right now:
…since the beginning of the Swords of Iron War, Elbit Systems has experienced a considerable increased demand for its solutions...
'Solutions', of course, is code for weapons and systems to kill Palestinians."
We therefore ask the House to -
- Ban Elbit Systems from receiving Australian Government contracts
- Cancel the existing $917m contract with Elbit Systems
- Make Hanwha find a new supplier for its ADF contract
from 38,331 citizens (Petition No. EN5997)
Nuclear Energy
Fission is moving towards obsolescence at an accelerated pace, as it is "out of step, out of time, out of place," and merely a temporary industry globally.
Commercial fusion electrical energy generation is a promising and innovative method of producing sustainable and clean energy alongside renewables.

By 2028, Helion is expected to start producing electricity from its first fusion commercial power plant, which will provide electricity to Microsoft. The plant will produce at least 50 MWe after an initial ramp-up period.
We therefore ask the House to include a fusion energy Act that will protect Australians and allow for the building and use of fusion energy machines in Australia
from 10 citizens (Petition No. EN5998)
Nuclear Energy
Commercial energy-generating fusion is our goal so it may provide all heavy industries with their own low cost clean dispatchable power plants.
"Now is exactly the wrong time to be too reliant on renewables and their generating capacity for electricity, yet that's exactly what many of the Australian state and AEMO grid are doing.
Fission is not a solution to the future, as it has many negative unresolved issues.

The solution has to be a total system solution using renewables, batteries, grid-attached hydrogen variable generation and Commercial energy-generating fusion to make our generations future-proof, secure, sovereignly safe and stable.
We therefore ask the House to develop separate fusion legislation as it is missing in current nuclear legislation and may lead to civil prosecutions if not developed.
from 13 citizens (Petition No. EN5999)
Nuclear Energy

Regarding Petition EN 5907, Australia should develop fusion commercial energy generation and propulsion systems. Which would be safer for our sailors and develop a Maritime fusion commercial industry as well as provide leadership in fusion commercial energy.

We therefore ask the House to fund research by the University of NSW. Qld and Adelaide, as well as the CSIRO and ANSTO into commercial fusion energy industry that will protect Australians, provide for space, maritime and land security and allow for the building and use of safe fusion energy machines in Australia.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6000)
Pakistan: General Election
Recent elections in Pakistan on February 8th have raised serious concerns about the integrity of the electoral process and the erosion of democratic values.

The elections have been marred by allegations of widespread fraud and manipulation, compromising the democratic process. The military's undue influence has distorted the outcome, turning what should be a democratic exercise into a charade to maintain power.

Numerous reports, including verified Form 45 results and international press coverage, provide irrefutable evidence of electoral malpractice. Despite legitimate victories by certain parties, such as PTI, the Pakistan Army unlawfully intervened to manipulate results, silencing the voice of the people.
The military's seizure of control and fabrication of fake Form 47 results highlight extensive interference, undermining the credibility of the elections and subverting democratic aspirations
We therefore ask the House to

We therefore urge the House to stand in solidarity with the people of Pakistan in their struggle to preserve democracy and uphold the fundamental principles of free and fair elections. Immediate action is imperative to denounce electoral fraud and restore democracy in Pakistan.

We must exert pressure on the Pakistani authorities to thoroughly investigate allegations of electoral fraud and ensure the upholding of democratic principles. The future of Pakistan's democracy hangs in the balance, and decisive action is necessary to safeguard the rights and freedoms of its citizens.
Furthermore, we demand that Pakistani authorities release any unlawfully detained political and media personalities with immediate effect and restore their right to a fair court trial.
from two citizens (Petition No. EN6002)
Grocery Prices

In the last 12 months, the leading supermarket's prices have risen by 9.6%; Woolworths and Coles should not have the authority to raise prices whenever they want. Both grocers already make billions of dollars a year, but at what cost? Families are struggling, and are being forced to choose between milk or bread. This must stop.
We therefore ask the House to illustrate that corporate companies cannot increase GST-free item prices by over 3% in the span of 12 months.
from 47 citizens (Petition No. EN6003)
Climate Change
