We are currently causing the global warming, specifically Earth's temperatures because of the burning of fossil fuels and science experiments. The consequence of global warming has affected our Earth by all the weather events in Australia. For example, Australia has the hottest winter in 2023, the bushfires in 2021, the flooding of Maribyrnong River in 2022, and so many more.
We therefore ask the House to help with the reduction of burning fossil fuels and science experiments.
from 12 citizens (Petition No. EN6005)
Cost of Living

Lowering the cost of living is really important for making life better for everyone and helping the economy grow. This is true for young people. When things cost less, it means young poeple don't have to worry as much about money. They can focus more on their jobs or school without stressing about paying for basic stuff like housing or healthcare.

When the cost of living goes down, it's like lifting a heavy weight off their shoulders. They can use their money for other things, like learning new skills. And when young people have more opportunities to do these things, their future gets much brighter.
We therefore ask the House to reduce the cost of living and make it easier for youg people to afford their needs.
from 26 citizens (Petition No. EN6011)
Schools: Disability Access
Not all learning spaces are wheelchair accessible, this needs to be changed as people who are in a wheelchair must have the ability to learn as easily as people who are not in a wheelchair.
We therefore ask the House to force all schools to make their spaces accessible to people in wheelchairs.
from 20 citizens (Petition No. EN6013)
Artificial Intelligence

AI is rapidly developing and eventually will run mostly likely everything, and we should learn to work with AI for the better future overall. By incorporating into schools we will have a better understanding of how AI works and what AI can be really used for, if we incorporate AI teens or young adults that are interested in AI can get properly started. These teens that learn to improve AI are the future of this generation.

AI can be a great thing to learn about, because many things are getting incorporated with AI like, banking, marketing, security, automation machines, finance etc. It can be a real good learning point for core important things.
We therefore ask the House to Incorporate or even consider the idea of AI into school learnings .
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6014)
Grocery Prices
Food inflation is a pressing issue because it strains household budgets and affects access to meals.
I'm asking for a change to raise awareness and action toward more affordable food systems.
We therefore ask the House to take further actions into the pressing issue of food inflation, which is causing significant financial strain for families.
from 25 citizens (Petition No. EN6016)
Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder
As a mother and a podcast host reaching out to over 100,000 other mothers, I am deeply concerned about the current situation regarding the medication lisdexamfetamine (Vvyance).
My children and I rely on this medication, but we are unable to obtain it from any pharmacies in Australia.

The U.S Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) recently rejected a request to increase production of a patented ingredient used in Vvyance. This decision has led to an alarming shortage that affects countless individuals around Australia
This shortage, exacerbated by global circumstances, has left countless individuals, both children, and adults, without access to essential treatment.

We urge the DEA to reconsider its decision and increase production immediately. The health and wellbeing of thousands are at stake here. We need your support in urging them towards this change that will positively impact so many lives.
We therefore ask the House to
Increase Manufacturing Quotas: We call upon the DEA to reconsider its decision and raise manufacturing quotas for lisdexamfetamine to meet the growing demand for Vyvanse in Australia and the world.

Facilitate Alternative Solutions: In the interim, we urge authorities to explore alternative solutions, such as importing generic versions of Vyvanse from other manufacturers or placing similar medications on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to provide patients with affordable alternatives.

Address Regulatory Hurdles: We call for a review of regulations surrounding ADHD medication in Australia, particularly those hindering the availability of generic alternatives, to ensure that patients are not left vulnerable to medication shortages in the future.
from 324 citizens (Petition No. EN6020)
Petitions
Advance the awareness of e-petitions in the community and to alert people to each e-petition as well as supporting local independent non-aligned newspapers.
We therefore ask the House to publish e-petitions weekly in independent non-aligned local and regional newspapers and advise of the link to participate.
from 19 citizens (Petition No. EN6021)
Australian Institute of Sport
The AIS is a failing system at the time which is rotting away while other countries sporting programs flourish. We need an American college like funding for a sports program under one banner.
We therefore ask the House to increase funding to the AIS to %2.5 of GDP
from three citizens (Petition No. EN6024)
Von Hippel-Lindau Syndrome

We, the undersigned, advocate for the inclusion of Belzutifan on the PBS to provide hope and improved outcomes for VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) patients. VHL is a rare, predominantly inherited cancer caused by a genetic mutation, affecting 1 in 36,000 individuals in Australia. The mutation leads to various cancers, including pancreatic neuroendocrine cancer, haemangioblastoma, phaechromocytomas, renal cell carcinoma, and endolymphatic sac tumors.
On average, VHL manifests at 26 years, requiring early screening due to its hereditary nature.

VHL falls under Neuroendocrine Cancers, with over 5,500 Australians diagnosed with Neuroendocrine Tumours (NETs) annually. NETs collectively rank as the 7th most diagnosed cancer in Australia. Presently, surgery or radiation therapy are the only available treatments for VHL, focusing on tumour removal without controlling growth.

Belzutifan, a proven effective medication available in the US and parts of the UK, is NOT accessible in Australia through the PBS, despite TGA approval and orphan drug classification. Affordability issues arise as Belzutifan costs $12,000 per month out of pocket.
We emphasize equal access to support services, treatments, and research for all cancers, asserting that VHL should not face discrimination.
We therefore ask the House to support the inclusion of Belzutifan on the PBS for the benefit of VHL patients in Australia. As soon as possible, every day counts.
from 17,803 citizens (Petition No. EN6026)
Mental Health

1/2/24 Our son Machlan Felix took his own life due to deficiencies in our mental health care and resources in Karratha. Help offered the last 10 months was unacceptable, insufficient and resulted in the loss of his life.

There's a high incidence of suicide amongst youth/adults in our community due to inadequate mental health professionals .Karratha needs access to reliable ,consistent Psyciatry/psychology and pediatrics for all mental health issues including ADHD, autism, anxiety, depression, mood disorders etc. Current referral methods, wait times and locum psychiatric rotations of 6 week intervals are not acceptable .Deemed a city with a $200 million state of the art hospital, no inpatient care for mental health patients .Specifically, we need a residential inpatient facility for mental health issues and residential psychiatrists who can provide consistent care, follow up, medication and correct diagnosis.We have the richest economy of WA with a high rate of suicide and inadequate professional help. RUOK isn't enough. It's time for the community to be heard. Everyone knows someone with mental health issues, let's get the help they need Instead of mourn the loss of life. Our son deserved more help, they didn't listen to us! Don't wait until it's too late It's time to be heard.

We therefore ask the House to provide the Karratha/Pilbara with an inpatient/outpatient mental health facility , adequate psychiatric professionals that are based residentially for consistent ongoing care, to give accurate and ongoing diagnosis, medication and treatment for both youth and adults suffering mental health issues
from 1,035 citizens (Petition No. EN6029)
Animal Welfare

I am a devoted rabbit lover, currently the proud parent to two bunnies. However, my joy is turning into sorrow as one of my rabbits has been infected with myxomatosis and the other is likely to follow suit. This cruel and agonising disease leaves us with no effective treatment options.

Myxomatosis is a lethal virus that affects rabbits, causing severe suffering before leading to death. In Australia, despite the availability of a vaccine overseas, it remains illegal due to fears it could interfere with population control measures for wild rabbits—an invasive species here.

However, this approach overlooks our domesticated pets who are part of our families. The current law puts them at risk and leaves us helpless when they contract this devastating disease. The vaccine has proven effective in countries like the UK where it's legalised (source: RSPCA UK).
We understand the need for controlling wild rabbit populations but believe there must be a way to protect our beloved pets too without compromising these efforts.

It's time we revisited these regulations and found a balanced solution that values both environmental concerns and animal welfare. Let's give domestic rabbits in Australia a fighting chance against myxomatosis by legalising its vaccine.

We therefore ask the House to revisit the legislation around the vaccine and let pet owners vaccinate their beloved animals. Controls can be put in place like microchipping to ensure domestic vaccinated rabbits aren't let into the wild even though wild rabbits have already developed a natural immunity against the disease.
from 63 citizens (Petition No. EN6031)
National Security

Since Pine Gap has been opened, it has been used as an operating base by the CIA to advance US interests at the behest of Australian sovereignty. The facility has been used to spy on global citizens, and organise criminal bombings on countries such as Cambodia. The US has interfered with our sovereignty by dismissing Gough Whitlam for threatening to close Pine Gap, thus showcasing a complete lack of respect for our sovereignty. Pine Gap is a threat to global privacy, world peace, and Australian sovereignty. Australia is a sovereign country of its own right, and is not simply an empty plot of land for the US to use to further its own agenda. It does not protect Australia, but rather makes it more vulnerable, and it is not in our sovereign interests to continue to maintain such a facility.
We therefore ask the House to close the Pine Gap facility, and investigate other US military bases in Australia.
from 144 citizens (Petition No. EN6032)
Construction Industry: Disability Access

People in wheelchairs are 70% more likely to have live in poverty due to not being able to access all schools or workplaces. People in wheelchairs should be able to have access to all places but we only ask for all future building built from 2025 onwards to require wheelchair access.
We therefore ask the House to make it mandatory for all building built from the 1st of January 2025 must require wheelchair access to all parts of the building.
from 30 citizens (Petition No. EN6034)
Homelessness

Poverty. Considering the amount of people who live on the streets, the ones who lay on the ground in sleeping bags to pieces of cardboard or none at all is a terrible situation you wouldn't want to be in yourself. Imagine the embarrassment they'd feel while people walk by, glancing over with pity or look over curiously at them and their small donation cup asking help from the public.

Having no opportunities to work and instead staying on the streets also does impact our society. By not being able to work or help participate in our society as most do in a way by working hours and so on can disrupt out whole system from working to getting paid then spending our money. Onto taxes, bills, groceries and etc.

We therefore ask the House to help support people in unfortunate circumstances and receive the restart they need to participate in society as a working citizen again. Which means I strive for at least the minimum amount of signatures needed as long or more to help convince the government to get more help towards the homeless. I'd hope to see them all in homes where they wouldn't lay out on the benches or grounds to sleep on with enough food and water.
from 16 citizens (Petition No. EN6036)
Parliamentarians' Entitlements

Adam Bandt, Bridget McKenzie, Andrew Willcox and other MP's have been spending excess tax payer dollars on non essential or hypocritical items such as: private charter flights and $200,000 of printing from a Green's party member (goes against the environment), travel allowance with over 100 days travelling in which they should be relocating if they are travelling that much.

We therefore ask the House to launch an inquiry into the excess MP spending of tax payers money and how this can be minimized with relocation of MP's or long term rentals, limiting private charter flights to only the PM and other high up individuals where it is necessary, be more attentive and thorough on what the MP's spend the tax payers money on to prevent corruption and misspending in the government
from 54 citizens (Petition No. EN6039)
Medicare

It is impossible in Queensland to access ANY free skin checks or follow up treatment. I went to a "bulk billing" clinic today for a skin check (after carefully researching bulk billed skin checks). I was horrified to be told it was $195!
I had $70 (fuel, bread, milk money for the week!) and had to negotiate paying off the remaining $125. I was reassured that I would receive $80.10 back through Medicare.
We live one of the highest skin cancer danger zones in the world and yet free checks and treatment are unavailable to us.
I find this negligent on behalf of our Government.
We therefore ask the House to review the current Medicare coverage for such an essential and life saving treatment.
from 73 citizens (Petition No. EN6040)
Cost of Living
Gone are the days where you could get a three course lunch menu and a dessert for 70 cents. These are the words spoken by Melbournian women, Rebecca Franks, in an article from yahoo. news (Figure 1).

This menu from 1975, shows how cheap all items were back in the days, and yes I know that there are such things in our world like inflation however in 49 years the prices of a sausage roll has increased 4344%. In 50 YEARS!!. thats 89% every single year. Thats far too much per year.

And charging students and excessive amount of money is ridiculous as well as the fact that the Marbibyrnong College is trying to make a profit, especially given the canteen is run by a private business and they have other sources of profit such as external sales. This makes me think that Bocca Foods is a bit selfish in the way they charge for their products

We therefore ask the House to introduce policies about how much products can increase by per year, as 89% per year is far too much. I believe a limit on 40% per year would be fair on both sides. I still believe their could be further changes made but this is a good start
from nine citizens (Petition No. EN6041)
Taxation
Foreign Investment in Australia outweighs Australian Investment by $850 Billion and yet the Business Council of Australia requires more Foreign Investment
Australian Super is investing more overseas than in Australia

Clearly the opportunity exists to Tax Multinationals 5% of the Australian Turnover without deductions to pay for Aged Care instead of ripping off the Cohort that paid 60 cents in the dollar tax when they worked overtime to have a pension and aged care
The Hawke Keating Government absorbed the oversubscribed Pension Fund into General Revenue
We therefore ask the House to tax Multinational Companys 5% of their Australian Turnover to pay for Aged Care instead of the Mums and Dads who supported this Country
from 18 citizens (Petition No. EN6045)
Seniors Connected Program: Village Hubs

The Dept of Ageing has advised that the Seniors Village Hub program under the Seniors Connected Program will cease from 30th June 2024. The current 12 locations have created safe and inclusive hubs of activities for Seniors who may have otherwise been socially isolated. The current sites have shown that with minimal core operating expenses that a large amount of Seniors have reconnected with their communities and peers, have demonstrated a reduction in mental health (therefore decreasing costs to Dept of Health by way of presentation to GP surgeries and Hospitals), increased capacity to engage in their communities (increased participation within local economics), attend social support independently (reduce costs to Aged Care packages).

We therefore ask the House to grant existing Senior Village Hubs the right to rollover any unspent funds at 30th June 2024 and receive ongoing funding to maintain core operating costs for a coordinator to continue the hard work already done to implement. The current model has shown a reduction on Aged Care Funding for Social Support and has empowered Seniors across the Country. Additional Hub locations across Australia should be considered also.
from 135 citizens (Petition No. EN6046)
New Vehicle Efficiency Standard

The supposed $12-$18,000 tax for new 4wd Utes will cause some vehicle manufacturers to leave Australia. Isuzu has already suggested that they may leave due to this new tax. This new tax is to push people to drive electric vehicles, these aren't for everyone and don't suit the needs of many, if not most, Australian. Australia has a very large 4wd community and almost every second car on the road is a 4wd vehicle. Not only that, but the secondhand market for electric vehicles is almost non-existent due to the cost of replacing the lithium batteries used to power these cars. Most electric cars go to scrap yards after 5-10 years due to the cost of replacing those batteries. 4wds are used in Australia for many things including recreational, farm work, holiday travel and even search and rescue missions by police. A lot of families purchase 4wd vehicles to be able to access remote locations to see the beautiful hidden gems this country has to offer, those sites will simply not be accessible with electric vehicles. Some trails to access these locations include things like water crossings and rock climbs. Lithium batteries will not survived the impact of rocks or being submerged under water and will cause a lot more damage to the environment.
We therefore ask the House to reconsider the Tax on 4wd vehicles.
from 55 citizens (Petition No. EN6047)
Pensions and Benefits

Unlike many countries around the world, Australia does not have free University education, welfare payments, or even living cost loans for students. Students are studying full-time 40 hours a week, and yet we are still somehow supposed to make a living wage?

Unless your parents earn below the poverty line, you cannot get any money from Centrelink if you are under 22. You can only get full payments if they together earn less than $62,000, and you receive nothing if they earn around $110,000 (well below the federal average wage).

And so, what happens to those students who receive no Centrelink or parental support, and need to leave home to study? We are forced to work near to full-time, while studying full time. How are students supposed to study while also having the time commitments and stress of supporting themselves financially?

Australia paints itself as a society where anyone can achieve anything. But keeping up full-time work and study is not remotely sustainable. A lot of people have to make the choice, and so many are forced to give up on higher education. A massive barrier to education exists. This barrier applies to people of all backgrounds, whose parents do not want to and cannot contribute to the costs of them living while studying.

We therefore ask the House to reduce the Centrelink age of independence to 18, or at the very least for the government to offer interest-free cost of living loans for university students, as is done in Britain.
from 68 citizens (Petition No. EN6048)
Medicinal Cannabis

To many are struggling with the cost of medical cannabis and are resorting back to pharmaceuticals tables opioids ect as they are only $6.90 on PBS or the month instead of $350-$750 a month depending on condition please sign this to start getting out voice heard
We therefore ask the House to push this into parliament asap kids adults are suffering they has to be a government subsidy to help
from 252 citizens (Petition No. EN6049)
Fossil Fuel Industry
All Australians are feeling the pinch of higher energy prices. However the policies of the major parties are either unsustainable or will come into effect too late.

We would like to propose a different policy. Rather then taxing our oil and gas industry, driving them out of our country, we should exonerate the oil and gas industries, on the proviso that they invest in refining a percentage of their product in Australia, as well as investing in gas power stations and gas storage.
This policy would be completed in two stages. The first stage would be the investing in the construction of gas facilities.

The second stage would be the refining of a certain percentage (say starting at 5%, and increasing gradually to 10 or 15%) of their product in Australia to be sold to our domestic market at a capped profit margin.

Any oil and gas companies which do not invest enough (this amount would need to be investigated), they could be taxed at a higher rate, and have this tax go towards the investment in the above gas facilities.

This solution could be completed in 2-5 years, along with investment in renewables, would allow Australia to have cheap, reliable energy, at minimal cost to Australian households. Also insulating Australia from future energy shocks.
We therefore ask the House to consider the above energy policy, to give relief to our families and industry, before irreparable damage is done to our economy and our way of life.
from 58 citizens (Petition No. EN6053)
Artificial Intelligence

The unchecked proliferation and misuse of images and videos facilitated by Artificial Intelligence (AI) technologies and its unchecked distribution via social and digital media pose a significant threat to individual privacy, the integrity of creative industries, and most importantly the broader societal fabric. The potential for AI to perpetuate and exacerbate violations of human rights and dignity underscores this urgency. AI-generated content, including deepfakes and AI-model/talent images, are being used in increasingly harmful ways—from spreading misinformation and manipulating public opinion to infringing on personal rights and exploiting images for illegal activities. Notably, the fashion and entertainment media sectors, pivotal to Australia's economy and cultural identity, stand at the brink of disruption due to the loss of jobs. The recent misuse of AI to generate non-consensual images of public figures and citizens highlights the urgent need for legislative action.
We therefore ask the House to Enact laws for clear labeling of AI-generated content, distinguishing it from human creations to combat misinformation.
Implement safeguards to ensure consent and control over the use and distribution of personal images, protecting against unauthorized AI exploitation.
Require transparency from entities using AI 'people' in all advertising and media, ensuring ethical use and accountability.
Develop a regulatory framework prioritizing ethical AI development, human rights, and privacy.
Invest in enforcement and public education on AI's risks and implications.

Immediate action is crucial to preserve the rights and dignities of individuals against AI's unchecked advances, echoing global calls for responsible regulation. We urge the House to lead with decisive and protective legislation.
from 984 citizens (Petition No. EN6054)
Personal Information and Privacy

New laws are required to fill the complete void to protect the public of current and advancing technologies in regards to communication and remote neuromonitoring. The Chilean Government has laws in place to stop functional magnetic resonance imaging technologies being using to read minds of citizens with out consent. The technologies could be used to steal very private information to blackmail and or sell to overseas countries, nation security issues. They could also be used to miss lead people / influence / murder etc etc. They can also be used by big corporations for advertising. The communication side could lead to many other problems from pranks to murder and a whole host of other issues, impersonations, unsolicited contact.
We therefore ask the House to engage in creating these laws to protect the public from both government, foreign government and large corporations.
from 222 citizens (Petition No. EN6055)
Electric Vehicles

Public EV chargers currently do not accept payments unless people sign up to an app. Many free ones still require people to sign up to the app and enter credit card details even though they are not going to be paying any money. With the number of different companies providing public chargers, this can quickly fill up a mobile phone with unnecessary apps.

We therefore ask the House to pass a law requiring public EV chargers to be used without signing up for apps. If no payment is necessary, the charger should work when the EV is plugged in. If payment is required, credit card processing facilities should be built into the chargers.
from 115 citizens (Petition No. EN6056)
International Humanitarian Assistance

The Australian Government needs to stop UNRWA funding immediately because if the Australian government keeps sending money to UNRWA it will get worse where UNRWA will keep building underground tunnels near UNRWA facilities and UNRWA teachers promoting more hatred to JEWS. They're also listed as a terrorist organisation and there are laws around it.
We therefore ask the House to stop the UNRWA funding immediately from the Australian government.
from 128 citizens (Petition No. EN6057)
Housing

I believe a combination of irresponsible migration intake and lack of protection for housing affordability and security are the largest factor contributing to the housing affordability crisis and availability of rental properties nationwide.

I believe as Australians we are big on fairness and opportunity. I believe we are big on all types of securities for all Australians and I feel the housing crisis is a significant security issue for the Australian people.
Iam asking on behalf of all Australian citizens that something be done to protect the rights and security for all Australian citizens nationwide.
Australian citizens shouldn't have to feel unsecured and unsafe or uncertain if they can afford to rent or face homelessness for their families.
These security issues are affecting all Australian citizens not just those who are trying to find or afford a rental property for their family.
Iam asking for change because as Australian citizens our priority is the well-being and safety of all our citizens.
Iam asking on behalf of all Australian citizens that something be done to address the issue effectively and as soon as possible.

We therefore ask the House to look into every possible avenue from affordability to availability of housing for rent and look into ways to prevent the housing crisis from getting much worse and increasing instability in the lives of all Australian citizens nationwide
from 118 citizens (Petition No. EN6058)

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

p.span: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

Australia should be a country where citizens, residents and visitors must be allowed to cherish and practice their faith without fear or shame. Sacred beliefs- held by faithful believers for thousands of years must be respected- AS LONG AS they are not contrary to the welfare and well-being of individuals in today's world.

Most recently, Black Bear Pictures has released a movie IMMACULATE which depicts Catholic Faith and uses the word Immaculate in the most sacrilegious context. That, too, is the time when Catholics are preparing to remember the death and resurrection of Jesus.
This movie and the people behind it, are attacking a faith that is held by 40 % of Australians. I do not approve it.
My Faith is as important as the liberties and freedoms of the persons promoting this movie.

We therefore ask the House to enact a legislation that curtail art expressions, movies, social media posts and other forms of communications in the public domain that ridicules religious beliefs and values that are not contrary to the values of a civilized society.
from six citizens (Petition No. EN6060)
New Vehicle Efficiency Standard

what will be the effect of the upcoming fuel efficiency standard on the resale value of current vehicles in Australia and how does the government going to ensure that the value of these vehicles does not fall due to the introduction of these standards?
We therefore ask the House to look at these standards as the cost of an EV will increase due to falling resale value.
from 14 citizens (Petition No. EN6063)
Russia: Presidential Election

The presidential "elections" in Russia in March 2024 took place amid brutal crackdowns against opposition, including unlawful arrests and assassinations. The endless evidence from this and previous parliament and presidential runs prove widespread violation of democratic procedures and pressure (including physical violence) against independent watchdogs and journalists.

Statistics says, up to 30 millions of extra votes were "cast" to guarantee Putin's victory. His result of 87% aims to become a powerful tool for the Kremlin's propaganda narrative of a battle between the Western and Russian civilizations. Its target audience is not only abroad, but also inside the country, as Putin needs to convince his own people that the vast majority of the country supports him.

The voting took place during brutal military aggression against Ukraine and its people. The Kremlin forced people to vote, including those from newly occupied territories—worth mention that the vast majority of countries including Australia didn't recognise the annexation.

Importantly, Putin's cronies explicitly say they don't want to stop until they capture the capital city of Ukraine and all the Northern coast of Black sea. It is a grave danger for the international order.

PACE has acknowledged that Russia became a dictatorship and called to consider Mr Putin an illegitimate leader after 2024. Several countries declared Russia a terrorist state. The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Mr Vladimir Putin.
We therefore ask the House to refuse to recognise the results of March 2024 elections and to impose sanctions on those responsible
from 145 citizens (Petition No. EN6065)
Youth Justice

It is well established that children generally don't understand the gravity of their behaviour. Those facing the justice system in Australia are the most disadvantaged. Incarcerating them perpetuates harm and trauma, and may lead to ongoing criminalisation. Evidence shows that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children are disproportionately targeted and harmed due to systemic and institutional racism. State and Territory Governments in Australia are are 26 times more likely to imprison these children than their non-Indigenous peers. The global minimum standard of 14 is based on neurotypical kids, but many who come into contact with the legal system have disabilities and impairments which require additional healthcare, support and understanding. Impaired children are being held in solitary confinement across the country, breaching UN Conventions on Torture and the Rights of the Child. The Australian Government must commit to funding therapeutic and non-punitive programs that keep children away from the legal system and out of prison. In place of the institutional failure we need community-driven solutions, intensive family support programs, trauma-informed mentorship and on-country learning that supports children so that they learn from their mistakes.
We therefore ask the House to commit to urgently raising the minimum age of criminal responsibility in Australia to at least 14, with no exceptions.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. PN0596)
Middle East

A permanent ceasefire is urgently needed in Gaza in order to bring an end to the terrible suffering and loss of life there, and enable a peaceful resolution in the region. We condemn both the terrorist attacks on Israeli civilians by armed Palestinian groups, and the Israeli Defence Force's attacks on Palestinian civilians and blockade of the Gaza strip which has prevented water, food, electricity and urgent medical supplies from entering. The Geneva Conventions and other instruments of the international human rights framework were introduced to ensure that such atrocities do not occur. It is essential that governments call on both sides of the conflict to adhere to these principles, cease all attacks on civilians, release all hostages and ensure the protection of human rights throughout the region. It will be necessary for Israel to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza and to lift its blockade. A comprehensive arms embargo should be imposed on all parties to the conflict, and the International Criminal Court's ongoing investigation into the situation should receive full support. The root cause of the conflict needs to to be addressed, including through dismantling Israel's system of apartheid against Palestinians.
We therefore ask the House to commit to urgently seeking a permanent ceasefire in Gaza in order to resolve the situation.
from 44 citizens (Petition No. PN0597)
Russia

It is a well-known and widely recognized fact that President Vladimir Putin has committed numerous crimes against his own people and the people of other nations. These crimes include politically motivated murders, such as the recent assassination of Alexei Navalny, repression against Putin's political opponents and against ordinary citizens who do not agree with his policies, torture of political prisoners, suppression of freedom of speech, usurpation of power, election rigging, unlawful alteration of the Russian Constitution, initiation of aggressive wars, and spreading aggressive propaganda among both Russians and the international community. This March, Russian authorities are holding so called presidential elections, which are organised with brutal violations of democratic principles and the rule of law. This procedure is also being conducted in the territories of Ukraine which are currently occupied by Russia. There is no doubt that Putin will proclaim himself the winner of these elections. We firmly believe that Australia must respond to Putin's blatant attempts to usurp power.

We therefore ask the House to recognise Vladimir Putin as illegitimate after the end of his current presidential term and to cease all contact with him, except for humanitarian contact and in the pursuit of peace.
from one citizen (Petition No. PN0602)

subdebateinfo.title: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

p.span: Freedom of Religious and Spiritual Practice

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that Falun Gong is a peaceful meditation practice based on the principles of Truthfulness, Compassion and Forbearance. Millions of Falun Gong practitioners in China have been fired, jailed, tortured or killed by the Chinese Communist regime since July 1999. There have been persistent reports of systematic, state-sanctioned organ harvesting from non-consenting prisoners of conscience in China, primarily practitioners of Falun Gong. The Independent China Tribunal, chaired by Sir Geoffrey Nice QC, concluded in its Final Judgement in 2019: "Forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one—and probably the main—source of organ supply" and that crimes against humanity against Falun Gong have been proved "beyond reasonable doubt".

We therefore ask the House to request the Prime Minister, Foreign Minister and Australian Government to: 1. Pass a motion or make a statement to openly request an immediate end to the 20-year persecution of Falun Gong in China and the immediate release of all Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience; 2. Urge China to immediately end the practice of organ harvesting from all prisoners of conscience and conduct a thorough public education campaign to ensure Australians do not unknowingly participate in forced organ harvesting in China; 3. Deny visas and bar entry to Chinese officials and policemen who are involved in the persecution of Falun Gong.
from 22,608 citizens (Petition No. PN0605)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (12:31): I present the following 56 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Susan

I refer to correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3732, with 386 signatures, concerning lodgement and processing arrangements for the Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) (Replacement stream) visa. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As you may be aware, prior to COVID-19 international travel restrictions which came into effect in March 2020, individuals were generally limited to just one subclass 485 visa in a lifetime as a primary holder. The replacement Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa was made available to recognise the commitment made by international students and to acknowledge the disruption to plans and lost time in Australia that COVID-19 and the associated travel restrictions caused.
I can advise the Australian Parliament and the Standing Committee of Petitions that subclass 485 Replacement stream applications for eligible individuals opened on 1 July 2022.

The Migration Strategy released on 11 December 2023 outlines the Government's vision for getting migration working for the nation and building a migration system that delivers for workers, businesses and all Australians. The actions in the Migration Strategy deliver a better managed migration system and are expected to help return migration to near pre-pandemic levels. The Government is recalibrating student and graduate visa settings to support both the education sector and Australia's migration needs and have decided the Replacement Stream and will be abolished, expected to happen mid-2024.

Whilst I acknowledge the petitioners' concerns and the proposals outlined in the petition, it is important to note that Australia's migration legislation, which prescribes the eligibility criteria to apply for and be granted a visa (generally) does not provide for the grant of a visa without an application and undergoing the associated assessment processes to determine eligibility for that visa.

In the lead up to accepting applications for this stream, nearly 30,000 current and former 485 visa holders had their visas extended or enlivened to 30 September 2022 to facilitate their travel to Australia and apply for the visa onshore.

You may be interested to know that between 1 July 2022 and 31 December 2023, the Department of Home Affairs received more than 9,300 subclass 485 Replacement stream visa applications. Of these, more than 9,000 applications resulted in the grant of the visa. Data related to the Temporary Graduate visa program is available publicly and published on the Australian Government data website at: https://www.data.gov.au.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3732 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3745 with three signatures, concerning visa validity periods for Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa holders. I apologise for the delay in responding.

As you may be aware, prior to COVID-19 international travel restrictions which came into effect in March 2020, individuals were generally limited to just one subclass 485 visa in a lifetime as a primary holder. The replacement Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa was made available to recognise the commitment made by international students and to acknowledge the disruption to plans and lost time in Australia that COVID-19 and the associated travel restrictions caused.
I can advise the Australian Parliament and the Standing Committee of Petitions that subclass 485 Replacement stream applications for eligible individuals opened on 1 July 2022.
To be eligible for a Replacement stream visa, applicants must:
hold a valid Temporary Graduate visa; or
have previously held a Temporary Graduate visa that expired on or after 1 February 2020; and
have been outside Australia at any time between 1 February 2020 and 15 December 2021.

You may be interested to know that between 1 July 2022 and 31 December 2023, the Department of Home Affairs received more than 9,300 subclass 485 Replacement stream visa applications. Of these, more than 9,000 applications resulted in the grant of the visa. Data related to the Temporary Graduate visa program is available publicly and published on the Australian Government data website at: https://www.data.gov.au.

I can also advise that on 21 February 2023, the Ministers for Education and Minister for Home Affairs jointly announced the extension of Temporary Graduate (subclass 485) visa Post Study Work Rights. From 1 July 2023, visa holders with a select degree may be eligible for an extended 2 years on their visa. The extension applies to key industries including health, teaching, engineering, agriculture and ICT.

The Migration Strategy released on 11 December 2023 outlines the Government's vision for getting migration working for the nation and building a migration system that delivers for workers, businesses and all Australians. The actions in the Migration Strategy deliver a better managed migration system and are expected to help return migration to near pre-pandemic levels. The Government is recalibrating student and graduate visa settings to support both the education sector and Australia's migration needs and have decided the Replacement Stream and extension of the Post Study Work Rights no longer align with policy priorities. Both options will be abolished, expected to happen mid-2024.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3745 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs enclosing petition EN3872 concerning processing times for Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) visa (subclass 491) and the Skilled Nominated (subclass 190) visa. I apologise for the delay in responding.

Processing on hand visa applications remains a priority for government. The Government provided $36.1 Million to fund an extra 500 positions that has supported temporary and permanent migration visa processing. The Government announced a further $48.1 Million in the 2023-24 Budget to deliver improvements in visa programs. These actions have reduced the number of on-hand visas applications.

Ministerial Direction No. 105 came into effect on 15 December 2023. Applications for employer sponsored visas in relation to all occupations to be carried out in regional Australia are the highest priority. This change supports Australia's regions and employers who continue to face critical shortages across all industries and all sectors.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3872 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles

Migration
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 28 November 2022 enclosing Petition EN4490, with 22 signatures, concerning inclusion of Child Care Worker into the Australian Skilled Migration Occupation Lists. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The occupation lists are for the purpose of identifying occupations in Australia where there is a genuine skills needs and where migration is an appropriate solution. The occupation of Child Care Worker (group leaders only) is currently on the Regional Occupation List (ROL) and is therefore an eligible occupation for skilled migration.

You may be aware that on 11 December 2023 the government released the Migration Strategy, which was developed to deliver a better managed and more targeted migration system. As part of the Strategy, the Government is progressing work to assess the effectiveness of the skilled migration occupation lists and expand pathways to permanent residence for temporary skilled sponsored workers.
On 25 November 2023, as part of these reforms, the Australian Government provided a simpler and clearer pathway to permanent residence for all Temporary Skill Shortage (TSS) visa holders, including:
removing the limit on the number of Short-term TSS applications visa holders can make in Australia;
expanding eligibility for the permanent employer sponsored visas to holders of all TSS visa streams;

removing the requirement for nominated occupations for permanent employer sponsored visas in the Temporary Residence Transition (TRT) stream to be assessed against a skilled migration occupation list; and
reducing the work experience requirement for the TRT stream to two years instead of three years.

Additionally, the concession to the age requirement for legacy Temporary Work Skilled (subclass 457) workers (introduced 1 July 2022), who were in Australia for 12 months during the pandemic from 1 February 2020 to 14 December 2021 will continue to be available until 30 June 2024.
These changes provide employers and holders of TSS visas with more certainty and will ensure Australia attracts and retains the skilled workers it needs.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN4490 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles

I refer to correspondence of 1 August 2023 enclosing Petition EN5151, with 21,965 signatures, concerning the request for a permanent residency pathway for temporary residents who have lived in Australia and supported the economy during the COVID-19 pandemic. Australia's universal, non-discriminatory migration programs are designed to support a safe, prosperous and united Australia.

Israel
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 11 September 2023 regarding petition number EN5265 calling for the Australian Government to denounce Israel and impose sanctions because of the current conflict in Gaza. I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, particularly those with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.

It is clear from the Government's engagements Australia has a respected voice in the Middle East, even if we are not a central player. I regularly raise Australia's view and press for progress towards peace in my engagements with counterparts in the Middle East, with partners including in Europe, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, and our region, as well as in multilateral forums.

We are using Australia's voice to advocate for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire and a pathway out of this conflict. As demonstrated by our vote at the United Nations, Australia is part of the international diplomatic effort urging an immediate humanitarian ceasefire. We see that as a critical, urgent step on the path to a permanent ceasefire. Like any ceasefire, this can't be one-sided. Hamas must cease its attacks, lay down its arms and release all hostages immediately.

In my visit to the region earlier this year, I made clear Australia's view that achieving peace and security for Israelis and Palestinians requires a two-state solution and the establishment of a Palestinian state. The status quo is failing everyone.

We are using our voice to express Australia's serious concern about the civilian death toll and dire humanitarian situation in Gaza. I have consistently emphasised that international law must be upheld—and that civilians and civilian infrastructure must be protected.

We are using our voice to advocate for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages by Hamas, and to condemn the October 7 terrorist attacks by Hamas. I have expressed our concern for hostages directly to families when I met with them in Australia and in Israel.

We are using our voice to express our grave concern at indications Israel is planning a ground offensive into Rafah. About 1.7 million Palestinians are taking refuge in the area. With the humanitarian situation in Gaza already dire, the impacts on Palestinian civilians from a major military operation would be catastrophic. Our message to Israel is: do not go down this path.

While I was in the West Bank, I met with Palestinian victims of violence by Israeli settlers. I made clear to my counterparts that this violence must cease and perpetrators must be held accountable. We consistently affirm that settlements are illegal under international law and a major impediment to peace.

Australia is using our voice to advocate for urgent humanitarian assistance to reach Palestinians in Gaza in desperate need, and to address the protracted refugee crisis in the region. While in Jordan, I announced an additional $21.5 million in humanitarian assistance.

In March, we announced that Australia will also support efforts by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates to assist with the delivery of vital humanitarian aid to civilians in Gaza. A Royal Australian Air Force C-17A Globemaster will deliver a supply of 140 Australian Defence Force aerial delivery parachutes for use in humanitarian assistance airdrops by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates.

The Australian Government is also providing an additional $4 million to UNICEF to provide urgent services, including for women and children, and $2 million to the new mechanism of the UN Senior Humanitarian and Reconstruction Coordinator for Gaza to facilitate expanded humanitarian access into Gaza.

These announcements bring Australia's total humanitarian contribution since this conflict began to $52.5 million and is in addition to Australia's core funding of $20.6 million for UNRWA, which has already been provided for this financial year.
The humanitarian crisis and the catastrophic consequences of regional escalation underlines why we are using our voice to advocate for parties to avoid the conflict spreading.

My engagements in the region underlined how heavily this conflict weighs on the peoples of this region. We mourn every Israeli and Palestinian innocent life which has been lost in this conflict and will continue to use our voice to support steps to peace in the region.
Israelis and Palestinians want and deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity.

Seeing the impacts of the conflict close up underscored to me the importance of remembering our common humanity, and how important it is that we safeguard peaceful dialogue in our community in Australia.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong

Australian Embassy: Ukraine
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email regarding petition number EN5629, regarding Australia's presence in Ukraine.

Two years on since Russia's full-scale invasion, the Australian Government continues to unequivocally support Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity. We have committed approximately $960 million in support to Ukraine, including $780 million in military assistance and $75 million in humanitarian funding to help meet the urgent needs of the Ukrainian people.

We have repeatedly condemned Russia's illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine, and we will continue to work with partners to maintain pressure on Russia. Australia has imposed a comprehensive suite of measures to hold Russia to account, including through 1,200+ sanctions, import and export bans and multilateral pressure.

The Australian Embassy to Ukraine continues to manage Australia's interests effectively from Warsaw. Australia's Embassy to Ukraine plays a vital role in supporting the provision of of Australian assistance to Ukraine. This is supported by active and close coordination between the Australian Government and Ukraine's Ambassador in Canberra.

Regarding the reopening of the Australian Embassy in Kyiv, the situation in Ukraine remains complex and challenging. Each country must work through its own safety and security considerations when it comes to managing its interests in Ukraine.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) is keeping the location of the Embassy under regular review. Consistent with usual practice for operations in challenging security environments, DFAT continues to undertake thorough security, and work health and safety risk assessments to ensure appropriate measures can be put in place to support operations in Kyiv.

The Australian Government has limited its bilateral engagement with Russia since its illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine. Australia maintains channels of communication with Russia in order to convey our strong opposition to the war as well as to communicate measures we have taken to ensure Russia pays a heavy price for its invasion. Our Embassy in Moscow also continues to provide consular assistance to Australians.
I hope this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong

These announcements bring Australia's total humanitarian contribution since this conflict began to $52.5 million and is in addition to Australia's core funding of $20.6 million for UNRWA, which has already been provided for this financial year.
The humanitarian crisis and the catastrophic consequences of regional escalation underlines why we are using our voice to advocate for parties to avoid the conflict spreading.

My engagements in the region underlined how heavily this conflict weighs on the peoples of this region. We mourn every Israeli and Palestinian innocent life which has been lost in this conflict and will continue to use our voice to support steps to peace in the region. Israelis and Palestinians want and deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity.

Seeing the impacts of the conflict close up underscored to me the importance of remembering our common humanity, and how important it is that we safeguard peaceful dialogue in our community in Australia.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition number EN5639 concerning the Israel-Hamas conflict. I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, particularly those with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.

It is clear from the Government's engagements Australia has a respected voice in the Middle East, even if we are not a central player. I regularly raise Australia's view and press for progress towards peace in my engagements with counterparts in the Middle East, with partners including in Europe, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, and our region, as well as in multilateral forums.

We are using Australia's voice to advocate for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire and a pathway out of this conflict. As demonstrated by our vote at the United Nations, Australia is part of the international diplomatic effort urging an immediate humanitarian ceasefire.

We see that as a critical, urgent step on the path to a permanent ceasefire. Like any ceasefire, this can't be one-sided. Hamas must cease its attacks, lay down its arms and release all hostages immediately.

In my visit to the region earlier this year, I made clear Australia's view that achieving peace and security for Israelis and Palestinians requires a two-state solution and the establishment of a Palestinian state. The status quo is failing everyone.

We are using our voice to express Australia's serious concern about the civilian death toll and dire humanitarian situation in Gaza. I have consistently emphasised that international law must be upheld—and that civilians and civilian infrastructure must be protected.

We are using our voice to advocate for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages by Hamas, and to condemn the October 7 terrorist attacks by Hamas. I have expressed our concern for hostages directly to families when I met with them in Australia and in Israel.

We are using our voice to express our grave concern at indications Israel is planning a ground offensive into Rafah. About 1.7 million Palestinians are taking refuge in the area. With the humanitarian situation in Gaza already dire, the impacts on Palestinian civilians from a major military operation would be catastrophic. Our message to Israel is: do not go down this path.

While I was in the West Bank, I met with Palestinian victims of violence by Israeli settlers. I made clear to my counterparts that this violence must cease and perpetrators must be held accountable. We consistently affirm that settlements are illegal under international law and a major impediment to peace.

Australia is using our voice to advocate for urgent humanitarian assistance to reach Palestinians in Gaza in desperate need, and to address the protracted refugee crisis in the region. While in Jordan, I announced an additional $21.5 million in humanitarian assistance.

In March, we announced that Australia will also support efforts by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates to assist with the delivery of vital humanitarian aid to civilians in Gaza. A Royal Australian Air Force C-17A Globemaster will deliver a supply of 140 Australian Defence Force aerial delivery parachutes for use in humanitarian assistance airdrops by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates.

The Australian Government is also providing an additional $4 million to UNICEF to provide urgent services, including for women and children, and $2 million to the new mechanism of the UN Senior Humanitarian and Reconstruction Coordinator for Gaza to facilitate expanded humanitarian access into Gaza.

These announcements bring Australia's total humanitarian contribution since this conflict began to $52.5 million and is in addition to Australia's core funding of $20.6 million for UNRWA, which has already been provided for this financial year.
The humanitarian crisis and the catastrophic consequences of regional escalation underlines why we are using our voice to advocate for parties to avoid the conflict spreading.

Australia and New Zealand made clear in a recent joint statement that we respect the independence of the International Court of Justice and the critical role it plays in upholding international law and the rules-based order. Decisions of the ICJ are binding on the parties to the case. Our shared expectation is that Israel act in accordance with the ICJ's ruling, including to enable the provision of basic services and humanitarian assistance.

My engagements in the region underlined how heavily this conflict weighs on the peoples of this region. We mourn every Israeli and Palestinian innocent life which has been lost in this conflict and will continue to use our voice to support steps to peace in the region. Israelis and Palestinians want and deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity.

Seeing the impacts of the conflict close up underscored to me the importance of remembering our common humanity, and how important it is that we safeguard peaceful dialogue in our community in Australia.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong

Occupied Palestinian Territories
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition EN5685 concerning Palestinian statehood.
The devastating crisis in Gaza has underscored the need for a political solution to the long-running conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

Australia supports Palestinians' right to self-determination, including the establishment of a Palestinian state alongside Israel, where Palestinians and Israelis can live side-by-side in peace, security and dignity within internationally recognised borders.

It is clear that the status quo is failing everyone. As a responsible member of the international community, Australia will continue to be guided by the principle of advancing the cause of peace and progress toward a just and enduring two-state solution. We will always consider how Australia can best encourage momentum toward that goal.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong

Road Safety
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of2 6 February 2024 regarding petition EN5709, which requests changes to the Assessing Fitness to Drive standard (AFTD).

I note that the petition expresses concerns about how the AFTD affects people with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). I would like to provide information about the AFTD in relation to the concerns raised in the petition.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for driver licensing in Australia. The Australian Government works with these governments to bring a harmonised approach to driver licensing regimes.

The AFTD is a joint publication of Austroads and the National Transport Commission (NTC) that details the medical standards for driver licensing for use by health professionals and state and te1Titory driver licensing authorities. The publication is intended for use by any health professional who is involved in assessing a person's fitness to drive or providing information to support fitness to drive. The publication is also a primary source of requirements for driver licensing authorities in making determinations about medical fitness to hold a driver licence.

The AFTD has been produced through an extensive consultation process involving medical, research and health experts, consumer groups, driver licensing authorities, and the transport industry. The NTC is responsible for developing the content ofthe guidelines and Austroads is responsible for publishing the guidelines and working with organisations who use them.
Austroads recently published a statement to clarify how neurodevelopmental conditions such as ASD are intended to be managed according to the AFTD.

They advise that the licensing criteria for a person with autism did not change in the 2022 edition of the AFTD, however additional guidance for health professionals on the management of neurodevelopmental disorders was included. This material was subject to expert review and public consultation during the development of the standards. The Austroads statement is available online at www.austroads.com.au/latest- news/assessing-fitness-to-drive-2022-no-changes-to-fitness-to-drive-requirements-for- people-diagnosed-with-autism.

Austroads notes the range and severity of ASD symptoms vary considerably and that people with an ASD diagnosis may not have symptoms impacting their ability to drive. As such, a diagnosis of ASD or another neurodevelopmental disorder does not compel a person to report their condition if their condition is not likely to affect their capacity to drive safely.
Austroads is accepting feedback on the AFTD through the page on the Austroads website listed above. The petitioners may wish to raise their concerns with Austroads directly via this process.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
cc. Senator the Hon Carol Brown, Assistant Minister for Infrastrncture and Transport
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King

International Students
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 enclosing Petition EN5774, with 808 signatures, concerning the reduction of the maximum age from 50 to 35 years for the Temporary Graduate visa (TGV).

I acknowledge the concerns raised regarding recent announcements by myself and the Minister for Home Affairs and Minister for Cyber Security, the Hon Clare O'Neil MP on the age limitation adjustment for the TGV program outlined in the Migration Strategy. The Migration Strategy repositions the TGV to support early career professionals develop the relevant work history they will need to progress to permanent residence.

Lowering the age eligibility for the TGV is part of broader structural reforms aimed to ensure that our most highly skilled international graduates drive long-term prosperity by transitioning to permanent visas as soon as possible. Key objectives of the Migration Strategy are to build stronger communities and reduce migrant worker exploitation by reducing the number of migrants who are permanently temporary.

Currently TGV applicants are required to be under the age of 50 when they apply for their visa, while the age cut off for permanent resident applicants is 45, which leaves many older graduates permanently temporary. Reducing the maximum eligible age for a TGV to 35 will benefit applicants by repositioning the visa as a product for early career professionals who can contribute to the Australian economy over a longer period, while setting boundaries for others with low prospects of becoming permanent residents.

Department of Home Affairs data indicates over the past five years, 94 per cent of TGV applicants are aged 35 years or younger at the time of grant, with the average aged 25. Once implemented, the Department will not be able to consider TGV applications from international graduates who are over the age of 35; however, these graduates may have access to other migration pathways, which have been enhanced as a part of the visa reforms.

International graduates who stay in Australia at the completion of their studies and pursue work opportunities help alleviate national skills shortages while making a valuable contribution to the Australian community. I want students to receive a high quality education in Australia, and to either choose to use their qualifications to join the global workforce or progress their career in Australia.

More specific details on implementation of TGV arrangements will be communicated ahead of a mid-2024 implementation. I encourage international students to continue to monitor the Department's website for updates.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5774 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
