Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Gaza
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of petition EN5832 concerning the clarity and consistency of advice on consular support to Australian citizens and permanent residents who have family members in Gaza. I know that this is an incredibly distressing time for Australians with extended family members in Gaza.

The Australian Government has now successfully assisted the vast majority of Australian citizens, permanent residents and immediate family members wanting to leave Gaza to do so. As a result, the government is seeking to help more parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents to depart Gaza and is advocating for all parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents with relevant authorities.

The Rafah border crossing is controlled by the Egyptian and Israeli authorities, not the Australian Government. They continue to put tight restrictions on who can cross. While we are doing all we can the Australian Government must work within this system, as do other countries with nationals in Gaza. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is in ongoing communication with Israeli and Egyptian authorities as well as likeminded countries.

As you are aware, there are a number of people who have valid Australian visas but do not meet the criteria for crossing the border out of Gaza. An Australian visa is an entry document for use upon arrival into Australia, it is not an exit permit for the country where a holder resides.
The Australian Government will continue to do all it can to advocate for Australians, permanent residents and their immediate family members and parents who wish to leave Gaza.

Israelis and Palestinians deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity. Australia will be guided by the principle of advancing the cause of peace and progress toward a just and enduring two-state solution. I will continue to engage like-minded partners on how Australia can best contribute to achieving that goal.
Thank you for taking the time to present this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
International Development Assistance
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 26 February 2024 regarding petition number EN5838 concerning Australian Government funding of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency {UNRWA).

The Australian Government made a decision to pause disbursement of $6 million in funding to UNRWA after serious allegations were made, resulting in UNRWA's dismissal of staff alleged to have been involved in the Hamas terrorist attacks of 7 October. The nature of the allegations warranted an immediate and appropriate response. The pause did not affect Australia's annual core funding of $20.6 million, which had already been provided for this financial year.

The Australian Government has been working with a group of donor countries and with UNRWA on the shared objective of ensuring the integrity of UNRWA's operations, rebuilding confidence and ensuring aid flows to Gazans in desperate need.

On 16 March, I announced that Australia would lift this temporary pause following steps to strengthen the integrity of UNRWA operations. Australia and our partners welcome the decisive actions from UNRWA and the UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres to strengthen the integrity of operations. This includes the UN Office of Internal Oversight Services' investigation of the allegations, and the independent review into UNRWA and the principle of neutrality, led by former French Foreign Minister, Catherine Colonna.

We also welcome UNRWA's immediate work to deliver an action plan for donors, including Australia. The plan includes strengthened internal controls to ensure its neutrality, including rigorous requirements of staff. We see this as an ongoing process of diligence and vigilance.

In disbursing the $6 million to UNRWA's flash appeal, Australia is finalising an updated funding agreement that will include stringent conditions such as guarantees of staff neutrality, and confidence in supply chains.

These steps provide the necessary confidence that the $6 million in urgent humanitarian funding to be released will go directly to those in need, satisfying Australia's rigorous humanitarian controls, sanctions and legal requirements.
Australia's decision is in line with steps taken by Canada, Sweden and the EU. It is expected that more countries that have paused will take a similar approach.

UNRWA must continue to do all it can to ensure the highest standards of governance and accountability are met, as its work is vital. There can be no tolerance for members of terrorist organisations working for UNRWA.
Only UNRWA has the infrastructure to receive and distribute aid on the scale needed right now in Gaza. We urge Israel to recognise its mandate and work transparently to support its integrity.

Successive Australian governments have funded the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, or UNRWA, since 1951. After taking office, the Albanese Government doubled Australia's annual funding to UNRWA to $20 million each year.

In resuming funding, the Government is responding to a humanitarian situation in Gaza which is dire, and only worsening. Since the beginning of this conflict Australia has committed $52.5 million in humanitarian assistance.
I appreciate you taking the time to write to me.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Syria
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email referring petition number EN5846, regarding Australia's relationship with Syria.

Australia recognises Syria as a nation state, but limits bilateral contact with the Syrian regime, and engages only when necessary. We stand resolutely against normalisation of relations with the Syrian regime, in line with other likeminded partners.

Australia supports a peaceful resolution to the Syria conflict, and we continue to urge all parties to the conflict to engage meaningfully with the political process established by UN Security Council Resolution 2254.

I note the petition's request that the Australian Government suspend sanctions on Syria. Sanctions are targeted measures designed to respond to specific situations of international concern. Australia has implemented an autonomous sanctions framework in relation to Syria since 2011 to reflect our grave concern at the Syrian regime's deeply disturbing and unacceptable use of violence against its people. These do not impede our ability to deliver humanitarian assistance to the Syrian people.

I also note the petition's request to establish a Parliamentary Friends of Syria Group. Country Friendship Groups are coordinated by the International and Parliamentary Relations Office; enquiries should be directed to ipro@aph.gov.au.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Refugee and Humanitarian Program: Gaza
Dear Chair

Thank you for your referral of petition EN5847 regarding a request to re-establish direct support to Palestinians evacuating from Gaza. I know that this is an incredibly distressing time for Australians with extended family members in Gaza.

The Australian Government has now successfully assisted the vast majority of Australian citizens, permanent residents and immediate family members wanting to leave Gaza to do so. As a result, the government is seeking to help more parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents to depart Gaza and is advocating for all parents of Australian citizens and permanent residents with relevant authorities.

The Rafah border crossing is controlled by the Egyptian and Israeli authorities, not the Australian Government. They continue to put tight restrictions on who can cross. While we are doing all we can the Australian Government must work within this system, as do other countries with nationals in Gaza. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is in ongoing communication with Israeli and Egyptian authorities as well as likeminded countries.

As you are aware, there are a number of people who have valid Australian visas but do not meet the criteria for crossing the border out of Gaza. An Australian visa is an entry document for use upon arrival into Australia, it is not an exit permit for the country where a holder resides.
We will continue to do all we can to advocate for Australians, permanent residents and their immediate family members and parents who wish to leave Gaza.

Israelis and Palestinians deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity. Australia will be guided by the principle of advancing the cause of peace and progress toward a just and enduring two-state solution. I will continue to engage like-minded partners on how Australia can best contribute to achieving that goal.
Thank you for taking the time to present this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email dated 26 February 2024, concerning petition number EN5849 relating to the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) Review (The Review).

I acknowledge the concerns raised in this petition and thank those who participated for raising these with me and the Australian Government. This letter is my response to the petition, as required under standing order 209(a).

Under current arrangements, regulation in the NDIS market has not been sufficiently proportionate to the risk of supports. This has led to gaps in regulatory oversight for some supports, as well as excessive burdens for lower-risk supports. As the NDIS market matures, the Government must ensure its regulatory settings continue to operate effectively and safeguard participants from unnecessary risks of harm, while also ensuring choice and control for participants over the way supports are delivered.

The Review outlined that further work will be required to design and implement this model, including consultation with people with disability, providers and other regulators, to determine how and where proportionality should be applied through a Provider Risk Framework. I appreciate that this reform would be a significant shift from the existing regulatory model, but it does not seek to limit choice and control which remains central to the NDIS. The Government understands that many participants have existing arrangements with providers and workers which they do not wish to change.

In January 2024, I established a Taskforce to commence this work. The NDIS Provider and Worker Registration Taskforce comprises eminent experts who bring deep knowledge and experience about the regulation of supports and services used by people with disability in the NDIS and contemporary regulatory practice, and lived experience of disability:
Ms Natalie Wade, disability rights lawyer (Chair);
Mr Michael Borowick JP, former ACTU Assistant Secretary;
The Hon Vicki O'Halloran AO CVO FAICD, former Administrator of the Northern Territory and former President of National Disability Services Australia; and
Professor Allan Fels AO, former chair of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

The Taskforce will consult with the disability community on the design and implementation of the new graduated risk-proportionate regulatory model. The Taskforce will also consult with the NDIS provider market, workforce representatives and other relevant stakeholders.

The Taskforce has commenced this period of consultation and is inviting submissions relating to the model. Further information can be found at www.engage.dss.gov.au/ndis-provider-and-worker-registration-taskforce.
Submissions are open until28 April2024. I have asked the Department of Social Services to provide the Taskforce with the petition you provided me.
Later this year, the Taskforce will provide me advice on the key design elements and implementation of new regulatory arrangements, including the Provider Risk Framework, so that those arrangements:

uphold the rights of people with disability including to determine their own best interests, improving their ability to exercise choice and control over the providers that they use, and this is central to design of the new regulatory model;
enable people who are self-managing in the NDIS and employing and engaging their own workers and providers to continue to do so;

reduce the potential for risk of harm to people with disability by taking a proportionate and risk-based approach to regulation that considers both provider and support risk, and the circumstances of the people who using those services; and
increase quality and innovation of services and supports for all NDIS participants.

In the NDIS, people with disability can expect to receive quality and innovative supports and be protected and prevented from experiencing harm. They can also expect to exercise their rights to choose the way in which their supports are delivered, including by whom, having access to all the information and support they need, or choose to use, to inform their decisions.
Thank you again for writing to me.
Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
National Disability Insurance Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 18 March 2024, concerning Petition Ministerial Referral (EN5855)—Access to the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS) for people living with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

I would like to confirm that all people with disability are able to access the NDIS if they meet the requirements set out in the National Disability Insurance Scheme Act 2013 (NDIS Act). Access to supports under the NDIS is not based on types of disability or on the presence of an underlying condition, illness or injury. People with ADHD can become NDIS participants if they meet the requirements set out in the NDIS Act, including providing evidence of the functional impact of their disability on activities of daily living. However, not all people with ADHD will meet the requirements in the NDIS Act.

Importantly though, the Australian Government is committed to progressing real change for the 4.5 million people with disability in Australia, including people with ADHD, whether they are participants of the NDIS or not. As I made clear during my address to the National Press Club on 7 December 2023, the Government's focus is on creating a unified, connected system of support with support levels matched to need. This approach is about making sure all people living with disability in Australia have the best chance at life.
Thank you for your referral of this petition.
Yours sincerely,
from the Minister for the National Disability Insurance Scheme, Mr Shorten
World Health Organization
Dear Susan
Thank you for your correspondence of 18 March 2024 in relation to Ministerial Petition EN5878.

The Australian Government is committed to strengthening national and global pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, and working with the Australian and international communities to be better prepared for the next pandemic. As referred to in this Ministerial Petition, one such reform under consideration through the World Health Organization (WHO) is the development of a new international instrument on pandemic preparedness, prevention and response.

The intent of this new instrument is to strengthen the international community's efforts in preventing, preparing for and responding to future pandemics. It provides an opportunity to reduce the risk and impact of health threats, such as that posed by COVID-19, by strengthening global health systems and disease surveillance, while enhancing equity and future pandemic response. Australia is actively engaged in the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body (INB), which is drafting and negotiating proposed text for the new instrument. For further information about the work of the INB, please see https://apps.who.int/gb/inb.

At this stage, none of the instrument provisions are agreed. Any new instrument that is negotiated will be subject to consideration by the Australian Parliament. This will include scrutiny by Parliament's Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT), which reviews and reports to the Parliament on all treaty actions proposed by the Government. JSCOT undertakes consultation on proposed treaties by inviting public submissions. Any proposed changes to Australian law to implement the new instrument will have to be considered and passed by Parliament.

The WHO is, and remains, a Member State led organisation. Under international law, Member States such as Australia retain sovereignty regarding their public health policies and responses. The WHO has no legal authority to force countries to accept any of its recommendations and can only provide aid an.d assistance at Member States' request. These arrangements will not be changed should a new instrument on pandemic preparedness, prevention and response be agreed.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler

International Humanitarian Assistance: Gaza
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 18 March 2024 regarding petition number EN5899 concerning funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA).
I know the conflict in the Middle East is deeply distressing for many Australians, particularly those with a connection to the region and loved ones directly impacted.

It is clear from the Government's engagements Australia has a respected voice in the Middle East, even if we are not a central player. I regularly raise Australia's view and press for progress towards peace in my engagements with counterparts in the Middle East, with partners including in Europe, Canada, Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States, and our region, as well as in multilateral forums.

We are using Australia's voice to advocate for an immediate humanitarian ceasefire and a pathway out of this conflict. As demonstrated by our vote at the United Nations, Australia is part of the international diplomatic effort urging an immediate humanitarian ceasefire. We see that as a critical, urgent step on the path to a permanent ceasefire. Like any ceasefire, this can't be one-sided. Hamas must cease its attacks, lay down its arms and release all hostages immediately.

In my visit to the region earlier this year, I made clear Australia's view that achieving peace and security for Israelis and Palestinians requires a two-state solution and the establishment of a Palestinian state. The status quo is failing everyone.

We are using our voice to express Australia's serious concern about the civilian death toll and dire humanitarian situation in Gaza. I have consistently emphasised that international law must be upheld—and that civilians and civilian infrastructure must be protected.

We are using our voice to advocate for the immediate and unconditional release of hostages by Hamas, and to condemn the October 7 terrorist attacks by Hamas. I have expressed our concern for hostages directly to families when I met with them in Australia and in Israel.

We are using our voice to express our grave concern at indications Israel is planning a ground offensive into Rafah. About 1.7 million Palestinians are taking refuge in the area. With the humanitarian situation in Gaza already dire, the impacts on Palestinian civilians from a major military operation would be catastrophic. Our message to Israel is: do not go down this path.

While I was in the West Bank, I met with Palestinian victims of violence by Israeli settlers. I made clear to my counterparts that this violence must cease and perpetrators must be held accountable. We consistently affirm that settlements are illegal under international law and a major impediment to peace.

Australia is using our voice to advocate for urgent humanitarian assistance to reach Palestinians in Gaza in desperate need, and to address the protracted refugee crisis in the region. While in Jordan, I announced an additional $21.5 million in humanitarian assistance.

In March, we announced that Australia will also support efforts by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates to assist with the delivery of vital humanitarian aid to civilians in Gaza. A Royal Australian Air Force C-17A Globemaster will deliver a supply of 140 Australian Defence Force aerial delivery parachutes for use in humanitarian assistance airdrops by Jordan and the United Arab Emirates.

The Australian Government is also providing an additional $4 million to UNICEF to provide urgent services, including for women and children, and $2 million to the new mechanism of the UN Senior Humanitarian and Reconstruction Coordinator for Gaza to facilitate expanded humanitarian access into Gaza.

These announcements bring Australia's total humanitarian contribution since this conflict began to $52.5 million and is in addition to Australia's core funding of $20.6 million for UNRWA, which has already been provided for this financial year.
The humanitarian crisis and the catastrophic consequences of regional escalation underlines why we are using our voice to advocate for parties to avoid the conflict spreading.
Australia is lifting its temporary pause on funding for the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) following steps to strengthen the integrity of UNRWA operations.

The decision to pause an additional $6 million in funding was taken after serious allegations were made, resulting in UNRWA's dismissal of staff alleged to have been involved in the Hamas terrorist attacks of 7 October.
The nature of the allegations warranted an immediate and appropriate response.

The Australian Government has been working with a group of donor countries and with UNRWA on the shared objective of ensuring the integrity of UNRWA's operations, rebuilding confidence and ensuring aid flows to Gazans in desperate need.

Australia and our partners welcome the decisive actions from UNRWA and the UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres to strengthen the integrity of operations. This includes the UN Office of Internal Oversight Services' investigation of the allegations, and the independent review into UNRWA and the principle of neutrality, led by former French Foreign Minister, Catherine Colonna.

We welcome UNRWA's immediate work to deliver an action plan for donors, including Australia. The plan includes strengthened internal controls to ensure its neutrality, including rigorous requirements of staff.
We see this as an ongoing process of diligence and vigilance.

In disbursing the $6 million to UNRWA's flash appeal, Australia is finalising an updated funding agreement that will include stringent conditions such as guarantees of staff neutrality, and confidence in supply chains.

These steps provide the necessary confidence that the $6 million in urgent humanitarian funding to be released will go directly to those in need, satisfying Australia's rigorous humanitarian controls, sanctions and legal requirements.
Australia's decision is in line with steps taken by Canada, Sweden and the EU. It is expected that more countries that have paused will take a similar approach.

UNRWA must continue to do all it can to ensure the highest standards of governance and accountability are met, as its work is vital. There can be no tolerance for members of terrorist organisations working for UNRWA.
Only UNRWA has the infrastructure to receive and distribute aid on the scale needed right now in Gaza. We urge Israel to recognise its mandate and work transparently to support its integrity.

Successive Australian governments have funded the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, or UNRWA, since 1951. After taking office, the Albanese Government doubled Australia's annual funding to UNRWA to $20 million each year.
In resuming funding, the Government is responding to a humanitarian situation in Gaza which is dire, and only worsening.

My engagements in the region underlined how heavily this conflict weighs on the peoples of this region. We mourn every Israeli and Palestinian innocent life which has been lost in this conflict and will continue to use our voice to support steps to peace in the region.
Israelis and Palestinians want and deserve to live their lives in peace, security and dignity.

Seeing the impacts of the conflict close up underscored to me the importance of remembering our common humanity, and how important it is that we safeguard peaceful dialogue in our community in Australia.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Child Support Scheme
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 18 March 2024 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning petition number EN5915, which relates to the Child Support Scheme. The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

All forms of family and domestic violence are unacceptable. The Australian Government is committed to ensuring single parents and their children receive the financial support they are entitled to, and that government systems don't exacerbate any abuse, including financial abuse.

I acknowledge the concerns raised in the petition about the interaction between care arrangements and the child support formula. Child support assessments are generally calculated on the actual care of the children, as this helps to ensure they are financially supported, regardless of with whom they reside.

I note that while the Government encourages involvement of both parents in their children's lives, the Child Support Scheme does not play any role in establishing or enforcing care arrangements for children. Disputes around parenting matters are best dealt with through mediation or dispute resolution or pursued through the family law system.

The Attorney-General, the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC MP is responsible for leading the Government's commitment to improving the family law system so that it is accessible, safer, simpler to use, and delivers justice and fairness for all Australian families. In particular, that the best interests of children are prioritised and placed at the centre of the family law system. This commitment is reflected in the recent passage of the Family Law Amendment Act 2023 which amended the Family Law Act 1975 to implement a streamlined parenting framework and simplify compliance and enforcement provisions for child-related orders.

Under child support legislation, where there is a care dispute between parents, an interim period may sometimes be available to recognise the court ordered care, but under current legislation an interim period can only apply at the start of a new child support assessment, where the breach of the care arrangement occurs at that point. This was confirmed by the Federal Court of Australia in February 2024.

The Government is taking action to address the uncertainty associated with interim care arrangements. The Social Services Legislation Amendment (Child Support and Family Assistance Technical Amendments) Bill 2024, which recently passed the Parliament, will enable an interim period to apply for disputed care changes that occur on or after the date the Bill commences. These provisions will commence after the Bill receives Royal Assent.
I note that the petition requests a review of the child support legislation.

As part of the 2023-24 Budget, the Government committed $5.1 million to implement key child support recommendations made by the Joint Select Committee on Australia's Family Law System (the Committee).

As part of the Government's response to the Committee's recommendations, the Government agreed to a range of recommendations to improve the Child Support Scheme over the longer term. The Government will be undertaking a number of reviews of the Child Support Scheme, including a review of compliance, private collection arrangements, and the interaction between Child Support and Family Tax Benefit.

The Government will also commission new research into the costs facing separated parents and has established a Child Support Expert Panel to ensure the child support formula reflects the current costs of raising children in Australia.
The Minister appreciates you bringing this matter to her attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliot
Environmental Management: Dingoes
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 24 March 2024 concerning the petition to place moratoriums on lethal dingo control and possession of 1080.

I understand the concerns about the use of 1080 in Australia. Protecting Australian's health and our environment, including unintended impacts on pets and other wildlife, is the Australian Government's priority in regulating agricultural and veterinary (agvet) chemicals such as 1080. The Australian Pesticides and Veterinary Medicines Authority (APVMA) rigorously assesses vertebrate poisons, such as 1080, before they are approved for use to ensure the safety of humans, animals and the environment.

The petition raises concerns about the impact of 1080 on non-target animals, such as pets and dingoes. The APVMA 2008 review found that, while poisoning of non-target animals can occur, when appropriate attention is paid to 1080 bait density, placement, timing, substrate and other matters, impacts can be minimised. Although alternatives do exist, they may not be suitable in all circumstances. Having a range of pest management tools ensures appropriate measures are available to respond to specific needs.

I will bring the potential for human health impact through the cultural practices and diets of our First Nation Peoples to the attention of the APVMA as a factor for their future prioritisation of chemical reconsideration activities.

In Australia, agvet chemicals are managed under a cooperative regulatory scheme between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments, with a shared division of responsibilities. Under this scheme, the Commonwealth is responsible for regulating agvet chemicals up to the point of supply, while the states and territories are responsible for controlling the use of chemicals after supply (commonly called control of use).

The potential misuse of agvet chemicals falls within the responsibility of the state and territory governments. I would encourage anyone to report specific instances of suspected non- compliance in the use of products such as 1080, such as the deliberate targeting of dingoes or other protected species, to the appropriate state or territory government agency, these details can be found at this website address: apvma.gov.au/node/3190.
Thank you again for bringing your concerns to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator Watt (Petition No. EN5918)
Overseas Students
Dear Ms Templeman

I refer to your correspondence of 31 March 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, enclosing Petition EN3877, with five signatures, seeking the provision of permanent residency to international students who studied onshore during the COVID-19 pandemic. I apologise for the delay in responding.

International students are an invaluable part of Australian communities, bringing new ideas and skills to enrich the fabric of our society, and a diversity of perspectives and experiences that are highly valued in our classrooms, and in the community.

The primary purpose of the student visa program is to facilitate the arrival of international students to live and study in Australia temporarily, in order to obtain a high quality education, and to either choose to use their qualifications to join the global workforce or apply the skills we need to a career in Australia.
You may be aware that on 11 December 2023 the government released the Migration Strategy, which was developed to deliver a better managed and more targeted migration system.

Through the Migration Strategy, the Government is recalibrating student and graduate visa settings to support both the education sector and Australia's migration needs, and create clearer pathways for student visa holders. These changes will help students to have a positive educational experience in Australia and support students with the skills Australia needs to transition to the workforce and help drive economic productivity.
Following their studies, student visa holders may seek to apply for a further stay in Australia, either temporarily or permanently, subject to meeting eligibility criteria.

The temporary graduate (subclass 485) visa provides recently graduated international students the opportunity to live and work in Australia following completion of their studies. This visa allows recently graduated students to gain temporary access to the Australian Labour market, and obtain practical work experience to accompany their qualification.

The skilled visa program also recognises the value of an Australian education. International students who have completed a bachelor's degree or higher, a diploma, an advanced diploma, or a trade qualification undertaken at an Australian educational institution are awarded additional points towards meeting the criteria for certain permanent skilled visas.

International students who wish to remain in Australia following their studies may wish to investigate their visa options, available on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3877 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Renewable Energy
Dear Chair

Thank you for referring a copy of petition EN5021 presented to the House of Representatives on 22 May 2023, regarding changes to the solar feed-in rate. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention and apologise for the delayed response.

The unprecedented wave of investment in rooftop solar over recent years has enabled more than one in three Australian households to access the benefits of rooftop solar, the highest uptake of rooftop solar in the world. The main benefit of installing rooftop solar is using what consumers generate during that day in their homes and avoiding the cost of purchasing electricity at the retail price.

The retail electricity tariff customers receive and the solar tariff consumers receive for exporting solar differs due to a range of reasons. The electricity tariff retailers charge consumers is made up of a broader range of costs: the wholesale price (the costs of generating electricity); network costs (the cost to maintain and operate the poles and wires that deliver energy to and from their home); environmental costs and retailer costs.

Each state and territory has different solar feed-in tariff rates and rules relating to solar tariffs. In jurisdictions where retail competition exists, retailers set solar feed-in tariffs to reflect a range of factors including their underlying cost base, their customers solar panel take-up rate and competitive considerations.

One of the best ways consumers can save money on energy prices is by shopping around for a better deal. There is a range of offers in New South Wales, the Australian Capital Territory, South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland which customers can compare at www.energymadeeasy.gov.au. Consumers living in Victoria can compare offers at www.compare.energy.vic.gov.au. Both websites are free to use and will provide consumers with information on offers available in the market, making it easier for them to find the best deal. It is important to note the deal with the best feed-in-tariff may not be the best deal for customers overall.

Lastly, in November 2023 Energy and Climate Change Ministers agreed to develop a National Consumer Energy Resources (CER) Roadmap—Powering Decarbonised Homes and Communities, to unlock consumer benefits for locally generated and stored power, deliver national reforms for efficient and effective CER integration, deliver on emissions and renewable energy commitments, and drive positive outcomes for all consumers, regardless of income, and the system as a whole.
Thank you for bringing the concerns of this petition to the government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Climate Change and Energy, Mr Bowen
Australian Constitution
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 16 October 2023 to the Hon Mark Dreyfus KC MP, Attorney-General, regarding a petition to request the House of Representatives to consider supporting a program to educate the public on the structure and function of Executive Government (reference EN5409).

Your email was referred to me for a response. Civics education and awareness is an essential part of the democratic process and supports public participation in our society and democracy. I understand this petition was brought about so that the public could understand what is meant by the 'Executive Government' in the context of the Referendum to establish an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice which may make representations to the Parliament and the Executive Government. Ahead of the 2023 referendum to recognise the First Peoples of Australia in the Constitution through a Voice, the Government took steps to ensure all Australians were provided with the necessary information to make an informed choice, including through delivery of a civics education program. The referendum did not pass, and the Government respects the decision of the Australian people.

Nevertheless, I am pleased to refer to existing public educational materials of various lengths and detail on the subject of the Executive Government. The Parliament of Australia website contains a range of publicly available materials and factsheets. 'Infosheet 20—The Australian system of government' contains a section on the Executive Government (https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/House_of_Representatives/Powers_practice_and_procedure/00_-_Infosheets/Infosheet_20_-_The_Australian_system_of_government). Furthermore, Chapter 2 of the 2018 seventh edition of the House of Representatives Practice contains a detailed subsection called 'The Constitution and Executive Government' (https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/House_of_Representatives/Powers_practice_and_procedure/Practice7).

Additionally, the Parliamentary Education Office webpage titled the 'Separation of powers: Parliament, Executive and Judiciary' is a short webpage on the principle of the separation of powers and is targeted at a younger audience (https://peo.gov.au/understand-our-parliament/how-parliament-works/system-of-government/separation-of-powers-parliament-executive-and-judiciary).
Thank you again for bringing the petition to the Australian Government's attention. I trust this information will be of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, Mr Gorman
Skilled Migration Program
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2023 enclosing Petition EN5417, with 510 signatures, concerning skilled regional visas and the qualifying period for Permanent Residence (Skilled Regional) (subclass 191).visa. I apologise for the delay in responding.

The Australian Government recognises the important and valuable contribution regional visa holders make in closing labour and skills gaps and supporting businesses and communities, through their commitment to living, working and studying in regional areas of Australia, while on a pathway to permanent residence.

The subclass 191 visa in the Regional Provisional stream, which commenced on 16 November 2022, is the pathway to permanent residence for eligible holders of Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) and Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (subclass 494) visas.
The main legislative requirements for the subclass 191 (Regional Provisional stream) visa are that the primary applicant must:
have held a Skilled Work Regional (Provisional) (subclass 491) or
Skilled Employer Sponsored Regional (Provisional) (subclass 494) visa for at least three years before applying;
provide notices of assessment issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) for three income years out of the five years of their eligible visa;
have complied with the conditions of the regional provisional visa, particularly the requirement to live, work and study only in a designated regional area of Australia; and
have complied with other conditions of the eligible visa held or previously held, including meeting character, health and security requirements.

While I understand applicants' reasons for wanting to qualify for permanent residence as soon as possible, there is no legislative power, which provides for time spent as a bridging visa holder to be counted towards eligibility for a subclass 191 visa. The time spent waiting for a qualifying visa to be processed does not alter the requirement to hold the visa for the prescribed period.

Further information about the subclass 191 visa, including all of the requirements, can be found on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-Iisting/skiIled-regional-191/regional-provisional.

While reducing visa application processing times is a priority for the Australian Government, skilled migration visa applications are processed in line with annual planning levels and according to priorities set through Ministerial Direction 105. Within this direction, priority is given to regional visa applicants with an employer sponsor, along with occupations from the health and teaching sectors. Further information about Skilled Migration processing priorities is available on the Department's website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-processing-times/skilled-visa- processing-priorities.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5417 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Corporate Governance: Online Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5478 on mandating online service providers to review and cease automatic rebilling for accounts.

Since 2017, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has been investigating harms on digital platforms. On 11 November 2022, it released its major interim report as part of the Digital Platform Services Inquiry 2020-2025 and made significant recommendations to address competition and consumer harms on digital platforms. This includes introducing economy-wide measures; measures to address scams, harmful apps, fake reviews and dispute resolution pathways on digital platforms; and a new digital competition regime. In its review, the ACCC identified issues such as security, privacy and billing concerns on apps and user accounts.

Treasury consulted on the ACCC's recommendations between 20 December 2022 and 15 February 2023 and on 8 December 2023, the Government released its response, supporting the recommendations in principle. The Government tasked Treasury and the Department of Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development, Communications and the Arts to improve the dispute resolution processes available to users of digital platforms; and for Treasury to consult on the design of a potential new digital competition regime. Government will consider the outcomes of these processes and take a harms-based approach to prioritising and addressing issues in digital platform markets.
Overall, the Government is committed to ensuring Australia has the right regulations to be a leading digital economy.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Asylum Seekers
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence 1 December 2023 enclosing Petition EN5536 with 26 signatures, concerning Australia's Humanitarian Program (the Program) impact.

The Australian Government is committed to compassionate and flexible Humanitarian and Settlement Programs that meet Australia's international protection obligations and position Australia as a global leader in international resettlement efforts.

A range of support services are provided to humanitarian entrants to Australia. These services are designed to build independence and help humanitarian entrants to integrate into their new community and participate fully in Australian life. Additionally, these services help to strengthen new arrivals' sense of belonging and increase social and economic participation, which in turn benefits all Australians.

Australia has a long history of welcoming refugees and other humanitarian entrants, and for providing assistance and support to help them settle in Australia. Australia is, and will remain, a multicultural society of people drawn from a rich variety of cultural backgrounds. The Government acknowledges and values the important social and economic contribution migrants and refugees have had through our nation's history.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5536 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Giles
Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN5599. The Government welcomes the public's views and appreciates the consideration that has been given to this matter.

In today's evolving banking landscape, there has been a noticeable shift towards telephone, online, and mobile app banking. These changes have resulted in a decrease in over-the-counter transactions, with more people turning to online banking options. This shift reflects changing consumer preferences and the influence of new technologies, but it has also led to banks reducing their branch networks.
The Government is concerned about the impact these changes have on communities in need of face-to-face banking services, as well as small businesses that rely on access to deposit and withdraw cash.

On 7 June 2023, the Government released its the 'Strategic Plan for Australia's Payments System', which details the policy priorities and objectives of the Government in relation to payments. One of the initiatives in the plan was 'Maintaining adequate access to cash'. As part of this, the Government will work with relevant agencies across the public sector and with industry to ensure that Australia has a sustainable cash distribution network that maintains adequate access to cash.

Additionally, the Government understands that some Australians still rely on cheques as a form of payment and the intention to wind down the cheques system by the end of2030 may impact individual's ability to. make payments for everyday transactions. In announcing an end-date for the cheques system, the Government is taking a leading role in ensuring this transition is managed in an orderly manner that limits adverse impacts on the community.

As part of the transition, on 8 December 2023, the Government released a consultation paper on the winding down of the cheques system to understand the opportunities and challenges it needs to prepare for in transitioning away from the cheques system. The paper explores current uses of cheques and options for transitioning to alternative payment methods.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Skin Cancer
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 February 2024 regarding support for a national skin check program. I recognise the contribution of Skin Check Champions and commend their work improving the early detection of skin cancer.

While the Australian Government does not fund a national skin cancer screening program, Australians can receive a skin check as part of a consultation with their general practitioner or specialist, which is supported through a range of Medicare Benefits Schedule Items.

The Government's screening policy is informed by the Population-based Screening Framework (Framework), which provides guidance for decision makers on issues to consider when introducing screening programs. While there is insufficient evidence to support a population-wide screening program for skin cancer in line with the Framework, evidence is emerging on the value of a targeted skin cancer screening program. However, more research is needed to test critical aspects of such a program.

The Government will continue considering the evidence for skin cancer screening, including alternative approaches to skin cancer detection and the role of artificial intelligence and emerging technologies.

You may be interested to know that I will soon host a roundtable with the sector to discuss skin cancer across the cancer continuum, in line with implementation of the Australian Cancer Plan. Planning is underway, and details will be confirmed shortly.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler (Petition No. 5615)
Embassy of Israel
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition number EN5625 concerning the closure of the Embassy of Israel in Australia.
Australia has a longstanding bilateral relationship with Israel.

Israel's diplomatic presence in Australia is essential to maintaining official channels of communications between our two governments, and Australia's diplomatic presence in Israel enables us to make direct representations to the Israeli Government on issues of concern.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Sri Lanka
Dear Ms Templeman
Thank you for your correspondence regarding petition EN5631 on human rights and democracy in Sri Lanka.

Australia and Sri Lanka share a strong and enduring relationship based on our aspirations for a peaceful, stable and prosperous lndo-Pacific. The Australian Government responded swiftly to Sri Lanka's unprecedented economic crisis in 2022 by providing $75 million to support the country's economic recovery. Through our development program, Australia is supporting the Sri Lankan government, non-profit institutions, and civil society to improve evidence-based policy and decision-making, deliver better services for communities, and increase the voice and agency of marginalised groups, including women.

Australia encourages Sri Lanka to strengthen the protection of human rights through bilateral, regional, and multilateral processes. This includes regularly raising human rights issues with Sri Lanka at the United Nations Human Rights Council, through our High Commission in Colombo, and with the Sri Lankan High Commission in Canberra. We also have regular discussions on human rights matters with a broad range of civil society actors in Sri Lanka and members of the Sri Lankan diaspora community in Australia.
Australia has consistently called for Sri Lanka's Prevention of Terrorism Act to be replaced in line with international human rights standards.

Australia is aware the Sri Lankan Government has recently gazetted a revised Anti- Terrorism Bill and remains concerned with aspects of the legislation. We are urging the Sri Lankan Government to continue consultations with all stakeholders before tabling a revised bill.

The constitution of Sri Lanka requires a presidential election to be held between September and October this year. The Australian High Commission in Colombo has made representations to the Government of Sri Lanka outlining Australia's expectations that these elections proceed in accordance with the constitution.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition number EN5633 concerning Australia making representations to the International Criminal Court (ICC} to prosecute the Government of Israel and Hamas.
The ICC has an active investigation into the situation in the Occupied Palestinian Territories. Australia does not propose to pre-empt ongoing prosecutorial and judicial processes in this matter.
Australia will continue to work for a just and enduring peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Immigration Detention
Dear Ms Templeman
I refer to your correspondence of 12 February 2024 enclosing Petition EN5644, which seeks a Royal Commission into Australia's regional processing arrangements.

While the Government considers a humane approach to irregular migration is required, it must also ensure that new people smuggling ventures do not reach our shores. As such, the Government has committed to maintaining strong border protection measures, including regional processing and boat turn backs where it is safe to do so.

The Government is upholding the policy setting that individuals who attempt to travel to Australia irregularly by boat, including transitory persons, will not settle in Australia. These policy settings have successfully stemmed the flow of irregular maritime ventures to Australia, disrupted people smuggling operations in the region and prevented loss of life at sea.

The Government of Nauru (GoN) is responsible for the implementation of regional processing arrangements in Nauru, including the management of individuals under those arrangements. Australia supports Nauru to implement arrangements through the provision of contracted service providers. Individuals in Nauru have access to health and welfare services and are provided support to engage with durable migration options.

Australia is party to the various international human rights treaties, including 1951 Convention relating to the Status of Refugees and its 1967 Protocol, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman, or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Australia takes its international obligations seriously and is committed to upholding them.
Since regional processing re-commenced in 2012, the Australian Parliament has undertaken several reviews of regional processing arrangements and circumstances arising from these arrangements.

Independent organisations, including the Commonwealth Ombudsman, the International Committee of the Red Cross, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights have conducted monitoring visits in Nauru. Transitory persons are free to communicate any concerns they may have. The Australian Government continues to support the monitoring role of non-government organisations. Noting that monitoring visits to Nauru require the permission of the GoN, responses to issues raised following such visits are matters for the GoN. The Australian Government will support the GoN to address any concerns.

Additionally, the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Legislation Committee (the Committee) scrutinises regional processing arrangements via Senate Estimates hearings a minimum of three times a year (in May, October and February). The Committee examines past and planned spending during public hearings, which are attended by officials from the Portfolio.
For these reasons, I do not support the House of Representatives considering the request contained within this petition.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN5644 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Home Affairs, Ms O'Neill
New Vehicle Efficiency Standard
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 to the Hon Chris Bowen MP, Minister for Climate Change and Energy, regarding Petition EN5647, which requests the House of Representatives to enact legislation for the adoption of European-equivalent emissions standards for all vehicles sold in Australia. Your email was referred to me, as this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Australia currently mandates Euro 5 noxious emission standards for new light vehicles. During previous consultations held over the last decade, key stakeholders advised that improvements to fuel quality standards must commence before Euro 6 can be mandated for light vehicles in Australia. This is because the higher levels of sulfur and aromatics currently permitted in petrol sold in Australia can affect the operability of Euro 6 vehicles, which are engineered to operate on cleaner fuels.

On 21 December 2023, the Australian Government announced it would mandate Euro 6 noxious emission standards for new light vehicle models, in conjunction with improved fuel quality standards from December 2025. New units of existing models supplied from

July 2028 will also need to comply. This timeline strikes a balance between maximising health and environmental benefits and ensuring manufacturers and refineries have sufficient time to implement the required changes, without disrupting the supply of fuel and new cars to Australian motorists. Equivalent standards have already been implemented for new trucks and buses supplied from 1 November 2024.

On 4 February 2024, Minister Bowen and I announced the Government's preferred model for the New Vehicle Efficiency Standard (the Standard), and released the Cleaner, Cheaper to Run Cars: The Australian New vehicle Efficiency Standard Consultation Impact Analysis.

The Government's preferred model would provide around $143 billion in net benefits for Australians by 2050, including around $108 billion in fuel cost savings and $5 billion in health benefits. Without intervention, transport is projected to be Australia's largest source of emissions by 2030 and the Government's preferred model for the Standard is estimated to reduce CO2 emissions by around 370 million tonnes by 2050.

Designing the best possible Standard to suit Australia's circumstances is complex, and we are committed to getting it right. Foundational work to introduce the Standard has included a substantial program of indust1y and public consultation, detailed economic modelling and consideration of the unique standards designed for other jurisdictions like New Zealand, the European Union and the United States. New legislation to support the introduction of the Standard will be introduced in Parliament in due course.
Thank you for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government, Ms Catherine King
Medicare: Imaging Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 February 2024 to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon Mark Butler MP, concerning petition number EN5699 regarding Medicare funding of GP Referred Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI).

The Australian Government is focused on delivering its priorities for the health and wellbeing of all Australians. Key among these priorities is strengthening Medicare to make it easier for Australians to see a doctor, cutting the cost of healthcare, and ensuring all Australians are treated with the respect they deserve and receive quality services to support them as they age.

The Government recognises MRI scans are an important diagnostic tool for medical practitioners in diagnosing, managing and treating illness. In 2022-23, the Government supported patient access to MRI scans through Medicare at a total cost of $545 million.

From 1 November 2022, the limitations on where an MRI machine could operate were removed in regional, rural and remote {Modified Monash Model 2 to 7) areas. This means MRI machines located in these areas are Medicare eligible when they satisfy the MRI requirements to deliver Medicare-eligible MRI services. This has significantly increased the number of Medicare eligible MRI machines available. Locations of Medicare-eligible MRI machines around Australia is available from the Department of Health and Aged Care's website at www.health.gov.au using the search term 'MRI locations'.

In terms of specific concerns about GP requests for MRI services, there are instances where services, including diagnostic imaging services, listed on the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), may have restrictions. These are based on clinical considerations such as gender, age, frequency of services, and requester requirements.
For an MRI scan to qualify for a Medicare rebate, the service must be:
listed on the MBS
performed on a Medicare-eligible MRI unit by a Medicare-eligible provider
requested by a specialist doctor, or by a general practitioner for a limited number of specified services.

Most MRI scans on the MBS must be requested by a specialist doctor. This is because the specialist is usually managing the conditions for which MRI scans can help with clinical decisions with the patient. There are however a limited number of MRI scans available on the MBS that may be requested by a· GP.

The MRI scans that can be requested by a GP were developed in consultation with the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners (RACGP) and the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Radiologists. The scans available were based on the appropriate scope of practice for GPs and based on clinical guidelines for the managing of patients. The RACGP has issued clinical guidance for MRI requesting which is available on the RACGP website at www.racgp.gov.au by using the search term 'MRI'.

The Government is also looking to unleash the potential of our health workforce and the Independent Scope of Practice Review is examining the barriers and incentives health practitioners face working to their full scope of practice. This is an independent review, led by Professor Mark Cormack. It is looking at the available evidence about health professionals' ability to deliver on their full scope of practice in primary care. Further information on this review including updates is available from the department's website by using the sear.ch term 'scope of practice review'.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
World Health Organization
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 26 February 2024 regarding Petition EN5836.

The Australian Government engages in global health forums to better protect the health and wellbeing of the Australian community. We know certain health threats are more likely to arise overseas and international cooperation helps Australia monitor and respond to these challenges. We also work to strengthen the global health system to prevent and respond more effectively to health challenges, including disease outbreaks and pandemics.

The Intergovernmental Negotiating Body, made up of the 194 member countries of the World Health Organization (WHO), was set up to draft and negotiate a new pandemic agreement (or 'treaty'). This is an important opportunity to strengthen global prevention and response systems and reduce the cost of future pandemics.

While the WHO hosts the negotiations, the new agreement is being negotiated by representatives of the 194 countries themselves, the WHO cannot decide or determine outcomes. Reports on the progress of negotiations is available at http:ljapps.who.int/gb/inb.

The WHO is, and remains, a Member State-led organisation. The Government is committed to pursuing Australia's priorities and advancing our national interests in global health forums. Please be assured that under international law, Member States such as Australia retain sovereignty regarding their public health policies.

The WHO has no legal authority to force countries to accept any of its recommendations and can only provide aid and assistance at Member States' request. Further, Australian law can only be changed by an act of the Parliament, not by any international treaty or other legal instrument.

At this stage, none of the instrument provisions are agreed. Any new instrument that is negotiated will be subject to appropriate scrutiny by the Parliamentary, including consideration by the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties (JSCOT).
As noted above, any changes to Australian law to implement the new instrument would also have to be considered and passed by Parliament.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Aged Care
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 12 February 2024 regarding Petition Number PN0588 about residential aged care service, The Laura Johnson Home.

The Aged Care Act 1997 requires aged care providers to provide safe and quality aged care at all times, in accordance with the Aged Care Quality Standards (Standards). The Aged Care Quality and Safety Commission (Commission) regulates the sector using these Standards (among other legal provisions) to fulfil its role to protect and improve the safety, health, wellbeing and quality of life of people receiving Australian Government funded aged care.

I am advised that the Commission undertook a comprehensive unannounced reaccreditation site audit at the service from 26 to 28 September 2023 to assess the service's performance against all 42 requirements of the Standards. Following the audit, the Commission found the service compliant with the Standards. A performance assessment report detailing the Commission's findings from the audit can be found on its website at www.agedcareguality.gov.au/service-and-reports.

The service is currently accredited until 14 March 2027. Throughout an accreditation period, the Commission will continue to monitor a service using the full range of information available to it. If the Commission identifies risks to the health, safety and/or wellbeing of residents at a service, it will take appropriate action to ensure that they are safe. More information about how the Commission assesses and monitors aged care services is available on its website at www.agedcarequality.gov.au/providers/assessment-monitoring.
Anyone with a concern about an aged care service should contact the Commission by telephone on 1800 951 822 or visit the website at www.agedcarequality.gov.au.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
cc: The Hon Anika Wells MP, Minister for Aged Care
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Middle East
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email of 12 February 2024 regarding petition number PN0591 concerning the call for a parliamentary inquiry into the possible involvement of Australians serving in the Israeli Defence Forces' operations in Gaza.
Australia's consistent position in the Hamas-lsrael conflict is to call for the protection of civilian lives and the observation of international humanitarian law.
Under the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code), it is an offence for Australians to engage in hostile activities overseas, unless serving in or with the armed forces of a foreign country.

The Government encourages all Australians who seek to serve with the armed forces of a foreign country to carefully consider their legal obligations, and ensure their conduct does not constitute a criminal offence.
Foreign fighters who have returned to Australia are considered by law enforcement and security agencies on a case-by-case basis.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
COMMITTEES
Public Works Joint Committee
Report

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (12:32): On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the committee's report No. 3 of 2024, Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation: nuclear medicine facility project.
Report made a parliamentary paper in accordance with standing order 39(e).

Mr PERRETT: by leave—On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the committee's third report for 2024. This report considers a proposal referred in November last year from the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation for its nuclear medicine facility project. The total cost of the proposed ANSTO project is $619.23 million. Since the late 1970s, ANSTO has produced a variety of nuclear medicines, supported scientific nuclear research and advised the government on matters relating to nuclear medicine. ANSTO produces nuclear medicines for diagnosis and treatment of many illnesses and currently supplies 75 to 80 per cent of all nuclear medicine used in Australia. This is between 10,000 and 12,000 procedures each week—time-bound, time-sensitive material shipped all around Australia overnight.

On average, every Australian is likely to benefit from nuclear medicine and will require at least two doses or two procedures during their lifetime. This project will secure Australia's access to a long-term study of vital nuclear medicines by replacing an existing, nearly half-century-old manufacturing facility at the Lucas Heights campus, which has reached the end of its useful life. The replacement facility will be a two-storey building with a site footprint of approximately 6½ thousand square metres. The new facility will be able to produce the nuclear medicines—technetium, lutetium and iodine—at a greater capacity than the existing facility, ensuring an Australian supply of nuclear medicine, even in the event of increasing demand. The facility will also support the export of nuclear medicine to our region.

Investment in the nuclear medicine sector has a range of economic benefits for the Australian public, especially given projected shortages in imaging and medicine capability worldwide. Socioeconomic benefits will flow to industry, healthcare professionals, the nuclear medicine research sector and, obviously, patients. Australia's ability to manufacture nuclear medicine products for domestic use is dependent on ANSTO's facilities at Lucas Heights. It is clear these treatments are continually evolving as new medical technologies develop. The new facility will continue to provide research facilities into emerging nuclear medicine technology.
The committee notes the ongoing question of nuclear waste and reiterates the importance of Australia obtaining a purpose-built facility for the storage and disposal of nuclear waste.

The committee would like to extend its thanks to all those who provided written and oral evidence in support of this inquiry. The committee—members of which I'm surrounded by at the moment—would also like to thank personnel from ANSTO for the tour, provided to the committee, of the Lucas Heights campus. It was very impressive. The committee was struck by the passion and commitment that staff have for their important roles, knowing that they are often involved in life or death situation for patients at the end of the process.
The committee recommends that it is expedient the proposed work be carried out. I commend the report to the House.
Economics Committee
Report

Dr MULINO (Fraser) (12:36): On behalf of the Standing Committee on Economics, I present a corrigendum to the committee's report entitled Better competition,better prices:Reporton the inquiry into promoting economic dynamism, competition and business formation.

subdebateinfo.title: National Security Legislation Amendment (Comprehensive Review and Other Measures No. 3) Bill 2023

p.span: National Security Legislation Amendment (Comprehensive Review and Other Measures No. 3) Bill 2023
Second Reading
Consideration resumed of the motion:
That this bill be now read a second time.

Mr HASTIE (Canning) (12:37): We in this House all know that we are living in a changing world, and with that change have come security challenges. We know that authoritarian powers are on the move, and the last two ASIO directors-general, Duncan Lewis and Mike Burgess, have both said that espionage and foreign interference are occurring in Australia at unprecedented levels. I think that last night ABC's Four Corners, which documented the intelligence activities undertaken by China's Ministry of Public Security, underscored that very point. So it's important that we make sure our legislative framework for our intelligence agencies is fit for purpose. We've got to make sure that our intelligence agencies, our intelligence officers and supporting personnel can do their jobs, on behalf of Australia, to protect us, maintain our security and defend our interests. That means we have to adapt our framework to make sure that it's fit for purpose as we see shifts in threats, technology and modes of statecraft.

That's why the Richardson review was commissioned in 2018, the same year that the former Turnbull government passed landmark, historic espionage and foreign interference legislation. The Comprehensive Review of the Legal Framework of the National Intelligence Community, also known as the Richardson review, was the most significant review of Australia's intelligence legislation since the Hope royal commissions in 1974 and in 1983. The majority of the National Security Legislation Amendment (Comprehensive Review and Other Measures No. 3) Bill 2023 deals with the 12 recommendations of the Richardson review, all of which the former coalition government agreed to in 2020, so we support this on a bipartisan basis.

The bill includes additional elements that the current government has identified in consultation with national security agencies. The bill contains a number of provisions to amend the ASIO Act, the Intelligence Services Act, the TIA Act and the Archives Act to support and provide increased oversight of our intelligence agencies. These reforms address those 12 recommendations. Separate to the recommendations, the bill clarifies the operation of existing provisions in the ASIO Act and the Intelligence Services Act and updates the publication offence in the ASIO Act. Very generally—for the Australian public—the measures in this bill will support Australia's national security agencies by strengthening identity protections for employees, particularly against the backdrop of increased espionage and foreign interference in this country; increasing operational flexibility and sharing of information; clarifying some authorities to provide greater certainty for our intelligence agencies; and supporting quicker processing of security clearance suitability assessments. This is actually really important. Our whole national security enterprise, from Defence through to the national intelligence community, is undergoing greater recruitment efforts, and, as people are onboarded into Defence or our intelligence community, they need to have security clearance. So speeding that process up is vital for our national security, particularly when you add in AUKUS and the need for defence industry, which supports AUKUS, to have people who have the highest clearances. This bill will also promote increased oversight of national security agencies by introducing additional safeguards to provide oversight of ASIO's work on security assessments and vetting and by limiting who can exercise certain powers.

We on this side of the House, the coalition, will always support sensible changes to ensure that Australian men and women serving in our intelligence agencies can do their jobs effectively—that they can gather the intelligence, on behalf of us, to keep us safe. That's why they do what they do. We need to ensure that they are subject to appropriate oversight, and that's why we support these amendments. As such, we support the passage of the bill.

Mr KHALIL (Wills) (12:41): The previous speaker, the member for Canning, is also a member of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, and I thank him and other colleagues for their work on that committee. We did a fair bit of work on this bill when it was referred to the committee, as part of our work in making recommendations to government to always try and improve national security legislation.

I want to say at the outset that this government's primary commitment is to keeping Australians safe and protecting Australians' way of life, and this legislation is part of that effort. It's part of the effort to ensure that we have all the necessary resources and frameworks in place for our intelligence agencies. Of course, many of the elements of this legislation, the National Security Legislation Amendment (Comprehensive Review and Other Measures No. 3) Bill 2023, flow from the intelligence comprehensive review. The key part of this bill is the enhancement of transparency, and the frameworks for transparency around our intelligence agencies and the work that they do, in what we call the NSLAB. We've done a lot of work in this space to ensure that our intelligence and security agencies have the tools and resources they need to do their job efficiently and effectively. That's been part of the work of the PJCIS in reviewing the bill. We've worked towards finding a bipartisan consensus within the committee to ensure that the bill is passed in the best possible way, which is in the national interest and will get the best possible result for our intelligence agencies. It is about a continual improvement of our national security laws to ensure that our agencies are well equipped to continue their work to keep Australians safe and, as I said, protect our way of life. The introduction of this bill is very much part of that framework.

Last year, the PJCIS released its report in relation to this bill, the NSLAB. As you have heard, Mr Deputy Speaker, the bill covers 12 recommendations of the 2019 Comprehensive Review of the Legal Framework of the National Intelligence Community. This is actually the third in a series of bills that directly respond to the recommendations of that comprehensive review. As I said, its primary purpose is to ensure our intelligence agencies remain able to undertake their important functions efficiently, effectively and, of course, with the appropriate oversight. In many respects this bill consolidates the secrecy offences in the Intelligence Services Act and creates stronger protection of the identities of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, ASIS, and the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, ASIO. That is a central element of the bill.

What I want to emphasise today are the amendments this act creates in relation to part IV of the ASIO Act, which relates to the agency's security assessment functions. These include improvements in the transparency and accountability of our intelligence agencies, a core objective of this bill. The comprehensive review that was released publicly in 2020 was the most significant independent review of Australia's collective intelligence legislation since the Hope royal commissions in 1974 and in 1983. That comprehensive review found that the legislative framework governing our intelligence agencies has been well maintained and largely fit for purpose but that targeted reforms are required to ensure our laws continue to keep pace with the ever-changing technological and security landscape. That has clearly been accelerated, particularly over the last decade and certainly over the last couple of years. The technological advances, the changes and the impacts and implications they have on our intelligence agencies and the work they do are profound, so it's critically important that we deliver these targeted reforms to keep pace with that increasingly complex environment—best described as our symmetric security landscape.
